column2: Notice is hereby given, pursuant to law, that the following proposed revocable consents, have been scheduled for a public hearing by the New York City Department of Transportation.&nbsp
column3: The hearing will be held at 55 Water Street, 9 th Floor, Room 945 commencing at 2:00 p.m. on Wednesday, October 16, 2013.&nbsp
column4: Interested parties can obtain copies of proposed agreements or request sign-language interpreters (with at least seven days prior notice) at 55 Water Street, 9 th Floor SW, New York, NY 10041, or by calling (212) 839-6550. &nbsp
column12: In the matter of a proposed revocable consent authorizing 520 Madison Owners, L.L.C. to continue to maintain and use a sidewalk clock, together with an electrical conduit, on the west sidewalk of Madison Avenue, north of East 53 rd Street, in the Borough of Manhattan. &nbsp

column103: the maintenance of a security deposit in the sum of $5,800 and the insurance shall be in the amount of One Million Dollars ($1,000,000) per occurrence, and Two Million Dollars ($2,000,000) aggregate &nbsp
column121: In the matter of a proposed revocable consent authorizing The Jamaica Hospital Medical Center to continue to maintain and use a conduit and pipe bank under and diagonally across 135 th Street south of 89 th Avenue, in the Borough of Queens.&nbsp
column122: The proposed revocable consent is for a term of ten years from July 1, 2012 to June 30, 2022 and provides among other terms and conditions for compensation payable to the City according to the following schedule: &nbsp
column376: the maintenance of a security deposit in the sum of $17,770 and the insurance shall be the amount of One Million Dollars (1,000,000) per occurrence, and Two Million Dollars ($2,000,000) aggregate. &nbsp
column384: In the matter of a proposed revocable consent authorizing Matrix Realty LLC to construct, maintain and use a sidewalk hatch in the south sidewalk of East 91 st Street, east of Lexington Avenue, in the Borough of Manhattan.&nbsp
column385: The proposed revocable consent is for a term of ten years from the date of approval by the Mayor to June 30, 2024 and provides among other terms and conditions for compensation payable to the City according to the following schedule: &nbsp
column402: From the approval date to June 30, 2014&nbsp
column641: the maintenance of a security deposit in the sum of $3,500 security deposit and the insurance shall be in the amount of One Million Dollars ($1,000,000) per occurrence, and Two Million Dollars ($2,000,000) aggregate. . #5&nbsp
column648: In the matter of a proposed revocable consent authorizing River Plate Property, LLC to construct, maintain and use steps and a fenced-in area on the north sidewalk of East 94 th Street, east of Park Avenue, in the Borough of Manhattan.&nbsp

column1: Notice is hereby given that pursuant to the provisions of Title 25, chapter 3 of the Administrative Code of the City of New York (Sections 25-307, 25-308, 25,309, 25-313, 25-318, 25-320) (formerly Chapter 8-A, Sections 207-6.0, 207-7.0, 207-12.0, 207-17.0, and 207-19.0), on Tuesday, October 08, 2013 at 9:30 A.M. in the morning of that day, a public hearing will be held in the Conference Room at 1 Centre Street, 9th
column2: Floor, Borough of Manhattan with respect to the following properties and then followed by a public meeting.&nbsp
column3: Any person requiring reasonable accommodation in order to participate in the hearing or attend the meeting should call or write the Landmarks Commission no later than five (5) business days before the hearing or meeting.

column1: 74 Kent Street-Eberhard Faber Pencil Company Historic District
A German Renaissance Revival style factory built c. 1904-08. Application is to alter the front facade, construct a rear extension and excavate the rear yard.
A neo-Classical style bank building with a designated banking hall built in 1906-08 and enlarged and altered in 1931-32. Application is to install a barrier-free access ramp.
A transitional Italianate/neo-Grec style rowhouse designed by Thomas B. Jackson and built in 1879.&nbsp
column2: Application is to enlarge window openings at the rear facade.

column1: An Italianate style rowhouse built c. 1866. Application is to replace windows and construct a rear yard addition.

A neo-Grec style rowhouse designed by Robert Dixon and built in 1888. Application is to legalize the installation of a security door and stoop gate without Landmarks Preservation Commission permit(s).
A French Second Empire style house built c.1870. Application is to construct a rear yard addition.
A rowhouse built in 1872-73. Application is to construct rooftop and rear yard additions.
A Greek Revival style rowhouse built c. 1850. Application is to construct a rear yard addition.
A rowhouse built in the 1850s. Application is to replace storefront infill and install a barrier-free access ramp.

column2: A rowhouse built before 1896. Application is to excavate the basement and rear yard, construct a rooftop stair bulkhead, and raise chimneys.

column1: An Italianate style rowhouse built in 1874-75. Application is to excavate the basement and rear yard and construct a rear yard addition.
116 Prospect Park West-Park Slope Historic District
A rowhouse built in 1896. Application is to install railings at the stoop and areaway, and legalize the installation of a roof deck without Landmarks Preservation Commission permit(s).
An Art Deco style apartment building designed by Philip Birnbaum and built in 1937. Application is to establish a Master Plan governing the future installation of windows.
A store and loft building designed by Henry Fernbach, built in 1880-81, and altered in 1941.&nbsp
column2: Application is to reconstruct the missing&nbsp
column3: top two floors of the building and construct a rooftop addition and bulkhead.&nbsp

column1: A store and loft building designed by Henry Fernbach, built in 1880-81, and altered in 1941.&nbsp
column2: Application is to request that the Landmarks Preservation Commission issue a report to the City Planning Commission relating to an application for a Modification of Use pursuant to Section 74-711 of the Zoning Resolution.&nbsp

column1: A late Federal style institutional building built in 1826 with associated later additions. Application is to demolish a building and additions, construct a new building, rear and rooftop additions, alter window openings, install new doors, a barrier-free access lift, rooftop mechanical equipment, replace windows and alter the areaway.
324 Lafayette Street, aka 159-165 Crosby Street-NoHo Historic District
A Renaissance Revival style store and warehouse building designed by Horenburger &amp
column2: Straub with Martin Johnson and built in 1897. Application is to install awnings and light fixtures, alter the fire escape and install HVAC equipment.

column1: An apartment house with Victorian Gothic influences, designed by F. T. Camp and built in 1888.&nbsp
column2: Application is to legalize the removal of historic fabric and facade alterations performed without Landmarks Preservation Commission permit(s).

column1: A Moderne style market building designed by H. Peter Henschien and Axel S. Hedman and built in 1936-37. Application is to install canvas wall signs, and a hanging sign.
A building designed by Sherida E. Paulsen and built in 2010. Application is to construct a rooftop addition.

A neo-Classical style factory building designed by Parker and Schaffer and built in 1926-27. Application is to alter ground floor openings, install storefront infill, and modify a barrier -free access ramp.
400-406 West 57th Street, aka 869 9th Avenue and 871-877 9th Avenue -The Windermere -Individual Landmark
An Eclectic style apartment complex consisting of three buildings designed by Theophilus G. Smith and built in 1880-81.&nbsp
column2: Application is to construct rooftop and rear yard additions, install rooftop mechanical equipment, alter the facades, install new windows, install new storefronts, alter the areaways and install a barrier-free access lift.&nbsp

column1: 400-406 West 57th Street, aka 869 9th Avenue and 871-877 9th Avenue -The Windermere-Individual Landmark
An Eclectic style apartment complex consisting of three buildings designed by Theophilus G. Smith and built in 1880-81.&nbsp
column2: Application is to request that the Landmarks Preservation Commission issue a report to the City Planning Commission relating to an application for a Modification of Use pursuant to Section 74-711 of the Zoning Resolution.&nbsp

column1: A Modern French style store and loft building designed by Schwartz &amp
column2: Gross and built in 1911-12. Application is to install new storefronts and entrance infill.

column1: An early 20th-century Commercial and neo-Gothic style store and loft building, designed by William Harvey Birkmire, and built in 1916-17.&nbsp
column2: Application is to install new storefronts and entrance infill, alter portions of the facade, and install flagpoles and signage.

column1: An Art Deco style skyscraper, designed by Sloan &amp
column3: Application is to establish a master plan governing the future installation of windows and louvers.

column1: 1552 Broadway, aka 167 West 46th Street-I. Miller Building - Individual Landmark
A commercial building altered by Louis H. Friedland in 1926 with theatrical sculptures by Alexander Stirling Calder. Application is to install vitrines and signage.
128 West 82nd Street -Upper West Side/ Central Park West Historic District
A Jacobean Revival style rowhouse designed by Emanuel Gandolfo and built in 1885-86.&nbsp
column2: Application is to alter the rear facade and rear addition.&nbsp

column1: 294 Columbus Avenue, aka 100 West 74th Street -Upper West Side/Central Park West Historic District
A neo-Grec and Renaissance Revival style flats building designed by Thom &amp
column2: Wilson, and built in 1886-87. Application is to replace storefront infill and install louvers, lighting and signage.

column1: 189 Columbus Avenue, aka 75-77 West 68th Street-Upper West Side/Central Park West Historic District

A Renaissance/Romanesque Revival style flats building designed by Edward Kilpatrick and built in 1893-94. Application is to legalize the installation of storefront infill without Landmarks Preservation Commission permits.
135 Central Park West-Upper West Side/Central Park West Historic District
A Beaux-Arts style apartment building designed by Clinton &amp
column2: Russell and built in 1904-07. Application is to modify ironwork.

column1: A Renaissance Revival style townhouse designed by Charles P.H. Gilbert and built in 1893-94. Application is to legalize rooftop construction without Landmarks Preservation Commission permits.
332 West 84th Street -Riverside-West End Historic District Extension I
A Romanesque Revival style rowhouse designed by Joseph H. Taft and built in 1888-89.&nbsp
column2: Application is to construct rooftop and rear yard additions.

column1: An Italian Renaissance style apartment building designed by Clinton and Russell and built in 1906-08. Application is to construct rooftop additions.
14 East 60th Street, aka 10-14 East 60th Street-Upper East Side Historic District
A Beaux-Arts style hotel building designed by R.C. Gildersleeve and built in 1902. Application is to replace a window, install signage, and alter steps at the ground story.
48 East 64th Street-Upper East Side Historic District
A neo-Grec style rowhouse, designed by John G. Prague, and built in 1883-84. Application is to construct rear additions and a rooftop bulkhead, and excavate the basement and rear yard.
764 St. Nicholas Avenue-Hamilton Heights-Sugar Hill Historic District
A Classical Revival style rowhouse designed by Paul T. Higgs and built in 1895. Application is to install signage.

A museum complex composed of portions of medieval buildings and modern structures designed by Charles Collens and constructed between 1934 and 1938. Application is to modify a masonry opening and replace a window.

column3: Notice of Public Hearing to Consider Conveying Property to The New York State Urban Development Corporation d/b/a Empire State Development in Accordance with Section 14 of the UDC Act, Chapter 174 &nbsp
column4: NOTICE IS HEREBY GIVEN THAT a Real Property Acquisition and Disposition Public Hearing will be held on October 16, 2013, at 22 Reade Street, 2 nd floor conference room, Manhattan at 10:00 a.m., relative to the conveyance of property located at 121 W 125 th Street, New York, NY, 10027, Tax Block 1910, p/o Lot 1 (&ldquo
column6: ). The Property is comprised of a parcel of land in Central Harlem, Borough of Manhattan, situated between Adam Clayton Powell Boulevard and Lenox Avenue on the north side of 125 th street, within a C4-7 zoning district. The proposed action is to facilitate an initiative by the Office of the Deputy Mayor for Economic Development, in coordination with the New York City Economic Development Corporation (NYCEDC) and the New York State Urban Development Corporation d/b/a Empire State Development (ESD), to allow for the implementation of approximately 450,000 gross square feet (gsf) of mixed-use residential, commercial and civic development (the &ldquo
column8: ). The Project would consist of a residential development (comprising approximately 100 dwelling units, of which approximately half would be affordable units)
column11: office space for the National Headquarters of the National Urban League
column13: a community facility or permitted substitute
column14: and up to 250 public parking spaces. The Property is currently a 160,000 gross square feet structure consisting of a 350 space public parking garage and 6 retail stores at grade level. Pursuant to Section 14 of the New York State Urban Development Corporation Act, Chapter 174, Section 1 of the Laws of 1968, as amended, by letter dated August 1, 2013, the President of ESD requested that the City convey its ownership interest in the Property to ESD, and certified that the conveyance is necessary and convenient for ESD&rsquo
column15: s corporate purposes, specifically for the implementation of the 121 West 125 th Street Land Use Improvement and Civic Project. The discretionary action required for the Project include: conveyance of City-owned property to ESD for the purpose of subsequent development. ESD, as lead agency, conducted an environmental review of the Project pursuant to the State Environmental Quality Review Act (SEQRA).&nbsp
column16: This review involved the preparation of a Technical Memorandum to assess whether any new or substantially different significant adverse impacts would result from the Project compared to what was disclosed and considered in the 2008 Environmental Impact Statement conducted for the 125 th Street corridor Rezoning and Related Actions.&nbsp
column17: ESD concluded that the Project would not result in any significant adverse impacts not previously identified, and therefore, the Project did not result in the need for a supplemental environmental impact statement. column3: ). The Property is comprised of a parcel of land in Central Harlem, Borough of Manhattan, situated between Adam Clayton Powell Boulevard and Lenox Avenue on the north side of 125<sup>th</sup> street, within a C4-7 zoning district. The proposed action is to facilitate an initiative by the Office of the Deputy Mayor for Economic Development, in coordination with the New York City Economic Development Corporation (NYCEDC) and the New York State Urban Development Corporation d/b/a Empire State Development (ESD), to allow for the implementation of approximately 450,000 gross square feet (gsf) of mixed-use residential, commercial and civic development (the &ldquo
column5: ). The Project would consist of a residential development (comprising approximately 100 dwelling units, of which approximately half would be affordable units)
column8: office space for the National Headquarters of the National Urban League
column10: a community facility or permitted substitute
column11: and up to 250 public parking spaces.

column1: The Property is currently a 160,000 gross square feet structure consisting of a 350 space public parking garage and 6 retail stores at grade level.

<strong>Pursuant to Section 14 of the New York State Urban Development Corporation Act, Chapter 174, Section 1 of the Laws of 1968, as amended, by letter dated August 1, 2013, the President of ESD requested that the City convey its ownership interest in the Property to ESD, and certified that the conveyance is necessary and convenient for ESD&rsquo
column2: s corporate purposes, specifically for the implementation of the 121 West 125th Street Land Use Improvement and Civic Project.

column1: The discretionary action required for the Project include: conveyance of City-owned property to ESD for the purpose of subsequent development.

column3: ESD concluded that the Project would not result in any significant adverse impacts not previously identified, and therefore, the Project did not result in the need for a supplemental environmental impact statement.

20130925108,2013-10-02 00:00:00.000,2013-10-02 00:00:00.000,1,806,152,NULL,13,0,,NULL,NULL,"Type I Negative Declaration - TMN902 Catspaw Rehabilitation, CEQR NO. 13HPD003M",NULL,NULL,NULL,NULL,NULL,NULL,NULL,NULL,NULL,NULL,NULL,NULL,user,1,user,2013-09-26 10:26:12.867,2013-09-25 14:46:13.077,29-26-6,user,NULL,NULL,20130925108,NULL,NULL,NULL,5,NULL," The project sponsor, Nite Homes HDFC, is seeking construction financing from HPD to rehabilitate two privately owned residential buildings located at 152 W. 124th Street and 158 W. 122nd Street in the Harlem neighborhood of Manhattan, Community District 10.&nbsp
column2: The proposed project would be financed through HPD&rsquo
column4: The 158 W. 122nd Street property is located within the boundaries of the State/National Register (S/NR)-listed Mount Morris Park Historic District.&nbsp
column5: This proposal is therefore considered a Type I action under SEQRA. &nbsp
column6: The two existing four- and five-story residential buildings located at 152 W. 124th Street (Block 1908, Lot 56) and 158 W. 122 Street (Block 1906, Lot 57) currently contain a total of 29 dwelling units, six of which are occupied.&nbsp
column7: Under the proposal, exterior and interior rehabilitation and reconfiguration would occur resulting in a total of 28 affordable dwelling units.&nbsp
column8: The proposed activities would include installation of new plumbing, heating, and electrical systems as well as upgrades to the roof, bathrooms, kitchens, and apartment windows.&nbsp
column9: No ground disturbance or changes to either building&rsquo
column10: s overall floor area, height, or footprint are proposed.&nbsp
column11: In the event that any State or Federal funding is sought in connection with the proposed rehabilitation work, consultation with the New York State Office of Parks, Recreation, and Historic Preservation (OPRHP) in accordance with Section 106 of the National Historic Preservation Act of 1966 would be required prior to the release of funds and commencement of any construction activity at the 158 W. 122nd Street property. ",NULL,NULL,NULL,NULL,NULL,NULL,NULL,"

column1: The project sponsor, Nite Homes HDFC, is seeking construction financing from HPD to rehabilitate two privately owned residential buildings located at 152 W. 124th Street and 158 W. 122nd Street in the Harlem neighborhood of Manhattan, Community District 10.&nbsp
column2: The proposed project would be financed through HPD&rsquo
column4: The 158 W. 122nd Street property is located within the boundaries of the State/National Register (S/NR)-listed Mount Morris Park Historic District.&nbsp
column5: This proposal is therefore considered a Type I action under SEQRA.

column1: The two existing four- and five-story residential buildings located at 152 W. 124th Street (Block 1908, Lot 56) and 158 W. 122 Street (Block 1906, Lot 57) currently contain a total of 29 dwelling units, six of which are occupied.&nbsp
column2: Under the proposal, exterior and interior rehabilitation and reconfiguration would occur resulting in a total of 28 affordable dwelling units.&nbsp
column3: The proposed activities would include installation of new plumbing, heating, and electrical systems as well as upgrades to the roof, bathrooms, kitchens, and apartment windows.&nbsp
column4: No ground disturbance or changes to either building&rsquo
column5: s overall floor area, height, or footprint are proposed.&nbsp
column6: In the event that any State or Federal funding is sought in connection with the proposed rehabilitation work, consultation with the New York State Office of Parks, Recreation, and Historic Preservation (OPRHP) in accordance with Section 106 of the National Historic Preservation Act of 1966 would be required prior to the release of funds and commencement of any construction activity at the 158 W. 122nd Street property.

column3: The New York City Industrial Business Zone Boundary Commission was convened on September 13, 2013 at 1:30 PM at 110 William Street, 4 th Floor, Conference Room 4A/B, New York, New York. The Industrial Business Zone Boundary Commission was convened to ratify proposals to modify the existing and additional Industrial Business Zone (IBZ) boundaries.&nbsp
column4: Maps for the ratified amendments to the IBZ boundaries are available in this issue of the City Record and can be found at www.nycedc.com/ibz ",NULL,NULL,NULL,NULL,NULL,NULL,NULL,"

column1: The New York City Industrial Business Zone Boundary Commission was convened on September 13, 2013 at 1:30 PM at 110 William Street, 4th Floor, Conference Room 4A/B, New York, New York.
The Industrial Business Zone Boundary Commission was convened to ratify proposals to modify the existing and additional Industrial Business Zone (IBZ) boundaries.&nbsp
column2: Maps for the ratified amendments to the IBZ boundaries are available in this issue of the City Record and can be found at www.nycedc.com/ibz

column1: NYC Department of City Planning announces the PUBLIC COMMENT PERIOD and PUBLIC HEARING for the Proposed 2014 Consolidated Plan. The thirty-day PUBLIC COMMENT PERIOD will begin on OCTOBER 10, 2013, and will end NOVEMBER 8, 2013.

A PUBLIC HEARING will be held on FRIDAY, NOVEMBER 8, 2013, beginning at 2:30 p.m. at 22 Reade Street, Spector Hall, New York, N.Y. 10007. The Public Hearing will be followed by a question and answer session with City agency representatives in attendance.
The 2014 Proposed Consolidated Plan contains the City'
column2: s annual application for four U.S. Department of Housing and Urban Development (HUD) Community Planning and Development programs: Community Development Block Grant (CDBG), HOME Investment Partnership (HOME), Emergency Solutions Grant (ESG), and Housing Opportunities for Persons with AIDS (HOPWA).

column1: Proposed Funding allocations for 2014 are as follows: CDBG $220 million
column4: and, HOPWA $53.533 million. This totals $342.273 million which will be used to meet the housing, homeless assistance, supportive housing services and community development needs within the City of New York in 2014.

column1: The 2014 Proposed Consolidated Plan consists of three volumes: Volume 1. Contains an Executive Summary that provides an overview of the proposed use of entitlement grant dollars during the calendar year and the public&rsquo
column2: s comments to the proposal and the Action Plan: One-Year Use of Funds
column4: s Supportive Housing Continuum of Care for the Homeless and Other Non-Homeless Special Needs Populations, and Other Actions, which are the statutory requirements of the Cranston-Gonzalez Housing Act&rsquo

column1: To obtain a free copy of the 2014 Proposed Consolidated Plan, please visit the City Planning Bookstore, 22 Reade Street, New York, N.Y. (Monday 12 pm to 4:00 pm,
column2: Tuesday thru Friday 10:00 am to 1:00 pm).

column1: Copies of the document can also be obtained at the following Department of City Planning Offices:
Also, the Proposed Plan will be made available for downloading through the internet via the Department&rsquo

Furthermore, copies of the Proposed 2014 Consolidated Plan will be available for review at the main public library in each of the five boroughs. Please call (212) 720-3337 for information on the closest library.

Written comments may be sent by close of business, November 8, 2013 to: Charles V. Sorrentino, New York City Consolidated Plan Coordinator, Department of City Planning, 22 Reade Street, 4N New York, New York 10007 FAX: (212) 720-3495, email: Proposed2014ConPlan@planning.nyc.gov.

column2: The Department of Probation (DOP) will release the IMPACT (Intensive Mentoring/Parents and Children Together) Program Concept Paper on October 11, 2013. This concept paper is the precursor to a forthcoming Request for Proposals (RFP) to provide community-based services to meet the specialized needs of adolescents sentenced to probation primarily through Adult Criminal Court.&nbsp
column4: IMPACT will primarily help youth sentenced as Juvenile Offenders (JOs) or Youth Offenders (YOs) address issues related to their wrongdoing through two components &ndash
column6: DOP will seek an appropriately qualified provider to deliver the IMPACT program to eligible youth on Probation.&nbsp
column7: All responses to this ad are due by November 8, 2013 and should be directed to: NYC Department of Probation, Eileen Parfrey-Smith, Agency Chief Contracting Officer, 33 Beaver Street, 21 st Floor, New York, NY 10004 or acco@probation.nyc.gov. ",NULL,NULL,NULL,NULL,NULL,NULL,NULL,"

column1: The Department of Probation (DOP) will release the IMPACT (Intensive Mentoring/Parents and Children Together) Program Concept Paper on October 11, 2013. This concept paper is the precursor to a forthcoming Request for Proposals (RFP) to provide community-based services to meet the specialized needs of adolescents sentenced to probation primarily through Adult Criminal Court.&nbsp
column3: IMPACT will primarily help youth sentenced as Juvenile Offenders (JOs) or Youth Offenders (YOs) address issues related to their wrongdoing through two components &ndash
column5: DOP will seek an appropriately qualified provider to deliver the IMPACT program to eligible youth on Probation.&nbsp
column6: All responses to this ad are due by November 8, 2013 and should be directed to: NYC Department of Probation, Eileen Parfrey-Smith, Agency Chief Contracting Officer, 33 Beaver Street, 21st Floor, New York, NY 10004 or acco@probation.nyc.gov.

column1: Notice of Intent to Issue New Solicitation Not Included in FY 2014 Annual Contracting Plan and Schedule
NOTICE IS HEREBY GIVEN that the Mayor will be issuing the following solicitation not included in the FY 2014 Annual Contracting Plan and Schedule that is published pursuant to New York City Charter §
Nature of services sought: FDNY seeks the services of a qualified contractor to provide development, installation, hosting and support for a predictive dialer system.
Start date of the proposed contract: 07/01/2014
End date of the proposed contract: 06/30/2019
Method of solicitation the agency intends to utilize: Competitive Sealed Proposal
Personnel in substantially similar titles within agency: None
Headcount of personnel in substantially similar titles within agency: 0
Notice of Intent to Extend Contract Not Included in FY 2014 Annual Contracting Plan and Schedule

NOTICE IS HEREBY GIVEN that the Mayor will be entering into the following extension of a contract not included in the FY 2014 Annual Contracting Plan and Schedule that is published pursuant to New York City Charter §
Vendor: Hazen and Sawyer, P.C/CH2M Hill New York, Inc./A Joint Venture
Nature of services: NYC Nitrogen Removal Research Program
Method of extension the agency intends to utilize: Amendment Extension
New start date of the proposed extended contract: 10/30/2013
New end date of the proposed extended contract: 10/29/2014
Modifications sought to the nature of services performed under the contract: None

Reason(s) the agency intends to extend the contract: To perform a Consent Order requirement from the First Amended Nitrogen Consent Judgment (FANCJ) Index No. 04-402174 (Superior Court, New York County, J. Feinman).
Personnel in substantially similar titles within agency: None
Headcount of personnel in substantially similar titles within agency: 0

column133: REQUEST FOR COMMENT REGARDING AN APPLICATION FOR A CERTIFICATION OF NO HARASSMENT &nbsp
column135: To: Occupants, Former Occupants, and Other Interested Parties &nbsp
column137: 2350 Broadway, Manhattan 87/13 September 3, 2010 to Present 12 West 120 th Street, Manhattan 88/13 September 3, 2010 to Present 124 West 121 st Street, Manhattan 89/13 September 3, 2010 to Present 449 West 162 nd Street, Manhattan 92/13 September 9, 2010 to Present 105 West 131 st Street, Manhattan 93/13 September 12, 2010 to Present 254 West 135 th Street, Manhattan 96/13 September 24, 2010 to Present 316 West 140 th Street, Manhattan 98/13 September 30, 2010 to Present &nbsp
column138: 366 Jefferson Avenue, Brooklyn 90/13 September 4, 2010 to Present 10 Hancock Street, Brooklyn 91/13 September 4, 2010 to Present 202 Mac Donough Street, Brooklyn 94/13 September 20, 2010 to Present a/k/a 202 MacDonough Street 151 Herkimer Street, Brooklyn 97/13 September 27, 2010 to Present &nbsp
column141: Before the Department of Buildings can issue a permit for the alteration or demolition of a single room occupancy multiple dwelling, the owner must obtain a &quot
column143: from the Department of Housing Preservation and Development (&ldquo
column145: ) stating that there has not been harassment of the building&#39
column146: s lawful occupants during a specified time period. Harassment is conduct by an owner that is intended to cause, or does cause, residents to leave or otherwise surrender any of their legal occupancy rights. It can include, but is not limited to, failure to provide essential services (such as heat, water, gas, or electricity), illegally locking out building residents, starting frivolous lawsuits, and using threats or physical force. &nbsp
column147: The owner of the building identified above has applied for a Certification of No Harassment. column22: Opportunity to comment on proposed amendments to rule 101-07, rule 103-01, and rule 103-05 relating to boiler inspection and reporting deadlines &nbsp
column163: New York City Department of Buildings &nbsp
column215: Pursuant to the authority vested in the Commissioner of Buildings by Sections 643 and 1043 of the New York City Charter and Article 303 of Title 28 of the New York City Administrative Code, and in accordance with Section 1043 of the Charter, the Department of Buildings proposes to amend Section 101-07, Section 103-01, and Section 103-05 of Chapter 100 of Title 1 of the Rules of the City of New York.&nbsp
column218: Prior to the hearing, you may submit written comments about the proposed amendment to Mr. Daly by mail or electronically through the NYC Rules website at http://www.nyc.gov/nycrules by November 8, 2013. &nbsp
column219: To request a sign language interpreter or other reasonable accommodation for a disability at the hearing, please contact Mr. Daly by October 22, 2013. &nbsp
column220: Written comments and a summary of oral comments received at the hearing will be available until December 9, 2013 between the hours of 9:00 a.m. and 5:00 p.m. at the Office of the Commissioner, Department of Buildings, 280 Broadway, 7 th floor, New York, NY 10007. &nbsp
column224: The following rule amendments are proposed pursuant to the authority of the Commissioner of Buildings under Section 643 and 1043(a) of the New York City Charter and Article 303 of Title 28 of the New York City Administrative Code. Article 303 requires annual inspections of boilers.&nbsp
column225: Section 28-303.4 authorizes the Commissioner to set the inspection cycle, and section 28-303.7 allows rules regarding the filing of inspection reports. &nbsp
column226: With the proposed amendments to these rules regarding the annual inspection cycles for boilers, the Department is addressing some administrative issues that affect the deadlines for inspection and submitting reports for high-pressure and low-pressure boilers. The proposed amendments would do the following: &nbsp
column227: Allow the current inspection cycle that started on January 1, 2013, as a result of the 2012 inspection cycle extension due to Hurricane Sandy, to end on December 31, 2013. All subsequent inspection cycles for years after 2013 will start on January 1 and end on December 31 of the calendar year. These changes would establish the same annual inspection cycle that was used prior to the Department&rsquo
column229: Create a conventional annual inspection cycle within a single calendar year that makes it easier for boiler owners to follow. These amendments will make it administratively easier for boiler owners and Department staff to identify the particular inspection cycle that the inspections and/or violations were filed and/or issued. &nbsp
column230: Allow the Department to more easily calculate fees. The Department charges monthly late fees for inspection reports filed after the inspection cycle deadline. Adjusting the annual boiler inspection cycle period to start on January 1 and end on December 31 would allow the Department to more easily calculate and determine when it should assess monthly late fees. &nbsp
column231: Make sure that the boiler owner is properly filing records with the Department that are consistent with the active boilers present in the building. These amendments will allow inspection records to be maintained more accurately and the Department to account for boilers in use in city buildings. &nbsp
column232: Alert the Department to the dangerous conditions caused by unregistered boilers. The Department deems unregistered boilers to be a dangerous condition that could threaten the life and safety of building occupants. These amendments allow the Department to be more aware of unregistered boilers by requiring inspectors to immediately notify the Department upon discovering an unregistered boiler during an inspection. &nbsp
column233: Add to the low pressure boiler rule a provision regarding expired inspections that is in the high pressure boiler rule. &nbsp
column238: denote mandatory requirements and may be used interchangeably in the rules of this department, unless otherwise specified or unless the context clearly indicates otherwise. &nbsp
column242: This rule was not included in the agency&rsquo
column243: s most recent regulatory agenda as it was not contemplated at the time the agenda was published. &nbsp
column248: Subparagraph (ii) of paragraph 5 of subdivision (c) of section 101-07 of title 1 of the rules of the city of New York is amended to read as follows: &nbsp
column249: (ii) [Effective January 1, 2009, periodic] Periodic boiler inspections required by section 28-303.2 of the Administrative Code shall be performed in compliance with the following requirements: &nbsp
column252: Clause (B) of subparagraph (ii) of paragraph 5 of subdivision (c) of section 101-07 of title 1 of the rules of the city of New York is amended to read as follows: &nbsp
column253: (B) A low pressure boiler annual inspection must be conducted between [November 16th of the preceding calendar year through November 15th] January 1st and December 31st of the calendar year for which an owner submits the report [is being submitted at a date that follows the preceding annual inspection by 6 months or more]. Low pressure boiler annual inspections must be conducted at least six months apart. &nbsp
column254: The inspector must verify that a valid department-issued boiler number is affixed to the boiler and such number must be used in all correspondence between the inspector and the department. If an inspection reveals any dangerous condition in a boiler that threatens life or safety and that requires an immediate shut down of the boiler, or reveals an unregistered boiler, the inspector must immediately notify the boiler division at the department of the condition via fax or email at the number or address provided on the department&#39
column258: Paragraphs 1, 3 and 4 of subdivision (c) of section 103-01 of title 1 of the rules of the city of New York are amended to read as follows: &nbsp
column259: (1) Filing deadline. For the low pressure boiler annual inspection report or any part [thereof] of that report , forty-five (45) days from the inspection date [of the inspection, but in no event later than December 31st of each calendar year]. &nbsp
column260: (3) Inspection cycle. [November 16th of the preceding calendar year] January 1st through [November 15th] December 31st of the calendar year for which the report is being submitted. Annual inspections must be at least six (6) months apart. &nbsp
column261: (4) Late filing. An inspection report or any part [thereof that is] of that report filed after the forty-five (45) day filing deadline but in no event more than twelve (12) months from the date of the inspection . &nbsp
column264: Paragraph 1 of subdivision (d) of section 103-01 of title 1 of the rules of the city of New York is amended to read as follows: &nbsp
column265: (1) Inspection and report filing. An owner [shall] must comply with the inspection requirements and [shall] must file low pressure boiler annual inspection reports [as provided for in &sect
column266: 101-07] pursuant to Article 303 of Title 28 of the Administrative Code and in accordance with Section 101-07 of this chapter. &nbsp
column269: Subdivisions (e), (f) and (g) of section 103-01 of title 1 of the rules of the city of New York are relettered as subdivisions (f), (g) and (h), respectively, and a new subdivision (e) is added to read as follows: &nbsp
column270: (e) Acceptance of filings. Inspection reports filed after the forty-five (45) day filing deadline but within twelve (12) months of the inspection date will be considered late filings and will be subject to the appropriate civil penalties as set forth in subdivision (f) of this section. Reports filed after such twelve (12) month period will be considered expired. In such cases, owners will be subject to the appropriate civil penalties for failure to file an inspection report, as set forth in subdivision (f) of this section, and the department will require a new inspection to be performed for the current inspection cycle and a new report filed in accordance with this section. &nbsp
column272: 6. Paragraphs 5 and 8 of subdivision (c) of section 103-05 of title 1 of the rules of the city of New York are amended to read as follows: &nbsp
column273: (5) Inspection cycle. [November 16th of the preceding calendar year] January 1st through [November 15th] December 31st of the calendar year for which an owner submits the report [is being submitted]. &nbsp
column274: (8) Late filing . An inspection report or any part [thereof that is] of that report filed after the forty-five (45) day filing deadline but in no event more than twelve (12) months from the date of the inspection . &nbsp
column276: 7. Paragraph 5 of subdivision (e) of section 103-05 of title 1 of the rules of the city of New York is amended to read as follows: &nbsp
column277: (5) The inspector [shall] must verify that a valid department-issued boiler number is affixed to the boiler, and [such] this number [shall] must be used in all correspondence between the inspector and the department. If an inspection reveals any dangerous condition in a boiler that threatens life or safety and that requires an immediate shutdown of the boiler, or reveals an unregistered boiler, the inspector [shall] must immediately notify the department&rsquo
column278: s boiler division of the condition via fax or email at the number or address provided on the department&rsquo
column281: 8. Subdivision (f) of section 103-05 of title 1 of the rules of the city of New York is amended to read as follows: &nbsp
column282: (f) Acceptance of filings. Inspection reports filed after the forty-five (45) day filing deadline but within twelve (12) months of the date the inspection was conducted [shall] will be considered late filings [upon payment of] and will be subject to the appropriate civil penalties as set forth in subdivision [(i)] (j) of this section. Reports filed after such twelve (12) month period [shall] will be [deemed] considered expired. In such cases, [the appropriate civil penalties shall be paid,] owners will be subject to the appropriate civil penalties for failure to file a report as set forth in subdivision (j) of this section, and the department will require a new inspection [shall] to be performed for the current inspection cycle and a new report filed in accordance with this section. &nbsp

column24: New York City Department of Buildings

column1: Pursuant to the authority vested in the Commissioner of Buildings by Sections 643 and 1043 of the New York City Charter and Article 303 of Title 28 of the New York City Administrative Code, and in accordance with Section 1043 of the Charter, the Department of Buildings proposes to amend Section 101-07, Section 103-01, and Section 103-05 of Chapter 100 of Title 1 of the Rules of the City of New York.&nbsp

Prior to the hearing, you may submit written comments about the proposed amendment to Mr. Daly by mail or electronically through the NYC Rules website at http://www.nyc.gov/nycrules by November 8, 2013.
To request a sign language interpreter or other reasonable accommodation for a disability at the hearing, please contact Mr. Daly by October 22, 2013.

Written comments and a summary of oral comments received at the hearing will be available until December 9, 2013 between the hours of 9:00 a.m. and 5:00 p.m. at the Office of the Commissioner, Department of Buildings, 280 Broadway, 7th floor, New York, NY 10007.

The following rule amendments are proposed pursuant to the authority of the Commissioner of Buildings under Section 643 and 1043(a) of the New York City Charter and Article 303 of Title 28 of the New York City Administrative Code. Article 303 requires annual inspections of boilers.&nbsp
column2: Section 28-303.4 authorizes the Commissioner to set the inspection cycle, and section 28-303.7 allows rules regarding the filing of inspection reports.

column1: With the proposed amendments to these rules regarding the annual inspection cycles for boilers, the Department is addressing some administrative issues that affect the deadlines for inspection and submitting reports for high-pressure and low-pressure boilers. The proposed amendments would do the following:

Allow the current inspection cycle that started on January 1, 2013, as a result of the 2012 inspection cycle extension due to Hurricane Sandy, to end on December 31, 2013. All subsequent inspection cycles for years after 2013 will start on January 1 and end on December 31 of the calendar year. These changes would establish the same annual inspection cycle that was used prior to the Department&rsquo

Create a conventional annual inspection cycle within a single calendar year that makes it easier for boiler owners to follow. These amendments will make it administratively easier for boiler owners and Department staff to identify the particular inspection cycle that the inspections and/or violations were filed and/or issued.

Allow the Department to more easily calculate fees. The Department charges monthly late fees for inspection reports filed after the inspection cycle deadline. Adjusting the annual boiler inspection cycle period to start on January 1 and end on December 31 would allow the Department to more easily calculate and determine when it should assess monthly late fees.

Make sure that the boiler owner is properly filing records with the Department that are consistent with the active boilers present in the building. These amendments will allow inspection records to be maintained more accurately and the Department to account for boilers in use in city buildings.

Alert the Department to the dangerous conditions caused by unregistered boilers. The Department deems unregistered boilers to be a dangerous condition that could threaten the life and safety of building occupants. These amendments allow the Department to be more aware of unregistered boilers by requiring inspectors to immediately notify the Department upon discovering an unregistered boiler during an inspection.
Add to the low pressure boiler rule a provision regarding expired inspections that is in the high pressure boiler rule.

column1: (B) A low pressure boiler annual inspection must be conducted between [November 16th of the preceding calendar year through November 15th] <u>January 1st and December 31st</u> of the calendar year for which <u>an owner submits</u> the report [is being submitted at a date that follows the preceding annual inspection by 6 months or more]. <u>Low pressure boiler annual inspections must be conducted at least six months apart.</u> &nbsp
column2: The inspector must verify that a <u>valid</u> department-issued boiler number is affixed to the boiler and such number must be used in all correspondence between the inspector and the department. If an inspection reveals any dangerous condition in a boiler that threatens life or safety and that requires an immediate shut down of the boiler, <u>or reveals an unregistered boiler,</u> the inspector must immediately notify the boiler division at the department of the condition via fax or email at the number or address provided on the department&#39

column3: Paragraphs 1, 3 and 4 of subdivision (c) of section 103-01 of title 1 of the rules of the city of New York are amended to read as follows:

column1: (1) Filing deadline. For the low pressure boiler annual inspection report or any part [thereof] of that report, forty-five (45) days from the inspection date [of the inspection, but in no event later than December 31st of each calendar year].

(3) Inspection cycle. [November 16th of the preceding calendar year] January 1st through [November 15th] December 31st of the calendar year for which the report is being submitted. Annual inspections must be at least six (6) months apart.

(4) Late filing. An inspection report or any part [thereof that is] of that report filed after the forty-five (45) day filing deadline but in no event more than twelve (12) months from the date of the inspection.

column3: Paragraph 1 of subdivision (d) of section 103-01 of title 1 of the rules of the city of New York is amended to read as follows:

column1: (1) Inspection and report filing. An owner [shall] <u>must</u> comply with the inspection requirements and [shall] <u>must</u> file low pressure boiler annual inspection reports [as provided for in &sect
column2: 101-07] pursuant to Article 303 of Title 28 of the Administrative Code and in accordance with Section 101-07 of this chapter.

column3: Subdivisions (e), (f) and (g) of section 103-01 of title 1 of the rules of the city of New York are relettered as subdivisions (f), (g) and (h), respectively, and a new subdivision (e) is added to read as follows:

column1: (e) Acceptance of filings. Inspection reports filed after the forty-five (45) day filing deadline but within twelve (12) months of the inspection date will be considered late filings and will be subject to the appropriate civil penalties as set forth in subdivision (f) of this section. Reports filed after such twelve (12) month period will be considered expired. In such cases, owners will be subject to the appropriate civil penalties for failure to file an inspection report, as set forth in subdivision (f) of this section, and the department will require a new inspection to be performed for the current inspection cycle and a new report filed in accordance with this section.

In such cases, [the appropriate civil penalties shall be paid,] owners will be subject to the appropriate civil penalties for failure to file a report as set forth in subdivision (j) of this section, and the department will require a new inspection [shall] to be performed for the current inspection cycle and a new report filed in accordance with this section.

column1: NOTICE IS HEREBY GIVEN that a Contract Public Hearing will be held on Thursday, October 17, 2013, at 49-51 Chambers Street (Bank Lobby), commencing at 10:00 AM on the following:

IN THE MATTER of a proposed contract between the Department of Health and Mental Hygiene and the Contractor listed below, for an Assertive Community Treatment program. The term of this contract shall be from June 1, 2013 to June 30, 2015 and contain two options to renew for the period of July 1, 2015 to June 30, 2018 and July 1, 2018 to June 30, 2021.
The proposed contractor was selected by means of the Required Authorized Source Method pursuant to Section 1-02(d)(2) of the Procurement Policy Board Rules.&nbsp

A draft copy of the proposed contract is available for public inspection at the New York City Department of Health and Mental Hygiene, Office of the Agency Chief Contracting Officer, 42-09 28<sup>th</sup> Street &ndash
column2: 17th Floor, Long Island City, NY 11101, from October 4, 2013 to October 17, 2013, excluding Saturdays, Sundays and Holidays, between the hours of 10:00 AM and 4:00 PM.

20131004104,2013-10-11 00:00:00.000,2013-10-18 00:00:00.000,5,156,118,NULL,13,0,,NULL,NULL,Medallion Auction,NULL,NULL,NULL,NULL,NULL,NULL,NULL,NULL,NULL,NULL,NULL,NULL,user,1,user,2013-10-04 17:54:57.520,2013-10-04 10:25:51.013,16-4-6,user,NULL,NULL,20131004104,NULL,NULL,NULL,5,NULL, Notice of Medallion Sale &nbsp
column3: Limousine Commission wishes to announce that 200 Accessible Minifleet Medallions will be offered for sale, in lots of two, through the receipt of sealed competitive bids.&nbsp
column4: The TLC will receive bids in person on November 7, 8, 12 and 13, 2013, from 9:00 A.M. through 12:00 Noon at its offices at 33 Beaver Street, 19th Floor, New York, NY 10004.&nbsp
column5: These bids will be publicly opened on November 14, 2013, commencing at 9:00 A.M. at the Tribeca Performing Arts Center, Borough of Manhattan Community College, 199 Chambers Street, New York, NY 10007.&nbsp
column7: s offices and the auction facility are wheelchair accessible. &nbsp
column8: All interested bidders must submit their sealed bids on November 7, 8, 12 or 13, 2013 between the hours of 9:00 A.M. and 12:00 Noon at the NYC TLC, 33 Beaver Street, 19th Floor, New York, NY 10004 &nbsp
column9: All bid packages must be delivered by hand. Please be prepared to present an ID to enter 33 Beaver Street. &nbsp
column10: Bids will not be accepted by mail. &nbsp
column11: The deadline to submit Bid Packages is 12:00 Noon on Wednesday, November 13, 2013. &nbsp
column12: All 200 medallions (or 100 lots) included in this auction have been set aside for use with wheelchair-accessible vehicles.&nbsp
column14: The ten highest non-winning bids will be held for Reserve Status. &nbsp
column15: The minimum upset price for Accessible Minifleet Medallions is $850,000 per medallion or $1,700,000 per lot. &nbsp
column16: Bid packages, bidding instructions, bidder requirements, ownership requirements and further details are available online at www.nyc.gov/taxi and at all TLC facilities.&nbsp
column19: Any request for a sign language interpreter or other form of reasonable accommodation for a disability at the November 14, 2013 auction must be submitted in writing, by telephone, or by TTY/TDD no later than November 8, 2013, to the Office of Legal Affairs at: &nbsp
column20: Taxi and Limousine Commission 33 Beaver St., 22 nd Floor New York, New York 10004 Telephone: 212-676-1135 Email:&nbsp

column2: Limousine Commission wishes to announce that 200 Accessible Minifleet Medallions will be offered for sale, in lots of two, through the receipt of sealed competitive bids.&nbsp
column3: The TLC will receive bids in person on November 7, 8, 12 and 13, 2013, from 9:00 A.M. through 12:00 Noon at its offices at 33 Beaver Street, 19th Floor, New York, NY 10004.&nbsp
column4: These bids will be publicly opened on November 14, 2013, commencing at 9:00 A.M. at the Tribeca Performing Arts Center, Borough of Manhattan Community College, 199 Chambers Street, New York, NY 10007.&nbsp
column6: s offices and the auction facility are wheelchair accessible.

The deadline to submit Bid Packages is 12:00 Noon on Wednesday, November 13, 2013.
All 200 medallions (or 100 lots) included in this auction have been set aside for use with wheelchair-accessible vehicles.&nbsp
The ten highest non-winning bids will be held for Reserve Status.
The minimum upset price for Accessible Minifleet Medallions is $850,000 per medallion or $1,700,000 per lot.
Bid packages, bidding instructions, bidder requirements, ownership requirements and further details are available online at www.nyc.gov/taxi and at all TLC facilities.

Any request for a sign language interpreter or other form of reasonable accommodation for a disability at the November 14, 2013 auction must be submitted in writing, by telephone, or by TTY/TDD no later than November 8, 2013, to the Office of Legal Affairs at:

column3: Notice of Adoption of a Rule Amendment Regarding price signage that must be posted by businesses selling petroleum products. &nbsp
column4: NOTICE IS HEREBY GIVEN PURSUANT TO THE AUTHORITY VESTED IN the Commissioner of the Department of Consumer Affairs (the &ldquo
column6: ) by Section 2203 of the New York City Charter and Section 20-675 of the Administrative Code of the City of New York and in accordance with the requirements of Section 1043 of the New York City Charter, of the adoption by the Department of Consumer Affairs (the &ldquo
column8: ) of an amendment to the rule regarding price signage that must be posted by businesses selling petroleum products. &nbsp
column10: This rule was proposed and published on August 16, 2013.&nbsp
column11: The required public hearing was held on September 16, 2013. &nbsp
column12: Statement of Basis and Purpose of Rule &nbsp
column13: The City Council enacted Local Law 9 of 2013 amending section 20-672 of the Administrative Code of the City of New York to require that all gas stations post road signs displaying the total selling price of gasoline or diesel motor fuel. The law also requires that, where the total selling price for purchases made with cash is less than for purchases made with another form of payment, such as debit or credit card, the road signs disclose the total selling price for cash, debit card and credit purchases.&nbsp
column14: The rule amends 6 RCNY 4-63(b) to implement the requirements of Local Law 9. &nbsp
column15: The rule amends 6 RCNY 4-63(b)(1) to require gas stations to post a road sign not less than 60 inches wide and 36 inches high advertising the price of the petroleum products for sale.&nbsp
column16: The current rule does not require such a sign, but only sets forth the required content of a sign if the gas station chooses to advertise the petroleum product for sale.&nbsp
column18: The rule adds a new subparagraph (iv) to 6 RCNY 4-63(b)(2) to require that, when the price of the petroleum product is less for a cash purchase than other forms of purchase, the mandated road sign and all other curb signs advertising the sale of gasoline and diesel motor fuel must display the total selling price per gallon with cash, debit card, credit card or other form of payment for each grade of the petroleum product offered for sale. &nbsp
column19: The rule amends subparagraph (ii) of section 4-63(b)(5) to require that the minimum type size used on the mandated road sign is at least 430 points to ensure that the price and other information can be read by motorists. &nbsp
column26: denote mandatory requirements and may be used interchangeably in the rules of this department, unless otherwise specified or unless the context clearly indicates otherwise. RULE &nbsp
column28: Subdivision (b) of section 4-63 of subchapter E of Chapter 4 of Title 6 of the rules of the City of New York is amended to read as follows: &nbsp
column29: (b) Required curb sign and other [Signs] signs not located on dispensing equipment. &nbsp
column30: (1) [Any sign, poster or placard used to display or refer to the price per gallon or used to advertise &ldquo
column34: or terms of like import, of petroleum products, including gasoline and diesel motor fuel, other than that used on a dispensing device, shall have a maximum size including the size of any frame, of 3 feet by 4 feet.]&nbsp
column35: Every location at which gasoline or diesel motor fuel is sold or offered for sale must maintain a sign, poster or placard clearly visible to drivers of approaching motor vehicles with dimensions not less than 60 inches in width by 36 inches in height. &nbsp
column36: (2) There shall be clearly displayed on [such] every sign, poster or [other display] placard used to display or refer to the price per gallon or used to advertise petroleum products, including gasoline and diesel motor fuel, other than that used on a dispensing device : &nbsp
column37: (i) On the upper portion of the sign, the name, trade name, brand, mark or symbol, and grade or quality classification of such product, or, if such products are sold without identification, such sign, placard or other display shall refer clearly to such products as unbranded
column39: (ii) the total selling price per unit of measure at which such product is customarily sold at retail which for gasoline or diesel motor fuel shall be by gallon
column41: (iii) in close proximity to the total selling price, the legend &ldquo
column44: (iv) when the total selling price of purchases made with cash is less than the total selling price for purchases made with credit card, debit card or other form of non-cash payment, the following words referring to method of payment listed in the following order from left to right: &ldquo
column53: Each grade of the petroleum product must be listed on a separate line.&nbsp
column54: Following the grade name, from left to right, each line must list the applicable price per method of payment beneath the corresponding method of payment listed, &ldquo
column312: (3) The total number of signs, posters and placards used to advertise &ldquo
column316: or selling prices of gasoline and diesel motor fuel shall not exceed the number of vehicular traffic streets upon which the service station faces. For the purpose of this section, signs used on dispensing devices shall not be included in the number of signs permitted to be displayed and a sandwich or &ldquo
column318: sign, placard or poster shall be considered one sign. &nbsp
column319: (4) Any sign, poster or placard shall be located within the building line of the service station. &nbsp
column320: (5) Letters and numbers on such signs shall conform to the following: &nbsp
column321: (i) All numbers referring to price shall be the same height, width and thickness except that where a tenth of a cent number is used, that number must be at least one half the size of the number to which it relates. &nbsp
column322: (ii) [All letters shall be of a height, width and thickness that is no greater than the size of the largest number on the sign, poster or placard referring to price.] Type size cannot be less than 430 points. &nbsp
column323: (iii) Identification of the gasoline or diesel motor fuel offered for sale and any non-numerical language distinguishing the total cash selling price from the total credit card, debit card or other form of non-cash payment selling price shall be in letters and numbers not less than one-half of the height, width and thickness of the numbers referring to price. &nbsp

column1: Notice of Adoption of a Rule Amendment Regarding price signage that must be posted by businesses selling petroleum products.
NOTICE IS HEREBY GIVEN PURSUANT TO THE AUTHORITY VESTED IN the Commissioner of the Department of Consumer Affairs (the &ldquo
column3: ) by Section 2203 of the New York City Charter and Section 20-675 of the Administrative Code of the City of New York and in accordance with the requirements of Section 1043 of the New York City Charter, of the adoption by the Department of Consumer Affairs (the &ldquo
column5: ) of an amendment to the rule regarding price signage that must be posted by businesses selling petroleum products. &nbsp

column1: This rule was proposed and published on August 16, 2013.&nbsp
column2: The required public hearing was held on September 16, 2013.

column1: Statement of Basis and Purpose of Rule

The City Council enacted Local Law 9 of 2013 amending section 20-672 of the Administrative Code of the City of New York to require that all gas stations post road signs displaying the total selling price of gasoline or diesel motor fuel. The law also requires that, where the total selling price for purchases made with cash is less than for purchases made with another form of payment, such as debit or credit card, the road signs disclose the total selling price for cash, debit card and credit purchases.&nbsp
column2: The rule amends 6 RCNY 4-63(b) to implement the requirements of Local Law 9.

column1: The rule amends 6 RCNY 4-63(b)(1) to require gas stations to post a road sign not less than 60 inches wide and 36 inches high advertising the price of the petroleum products for sale.&nbsp
column2: The current rule does not require such a sign, but only sets forth the required content of a sign if the gas station chooses to advertise the petroleum product for sale.&nbsp

column1: The rule adds a new subparagraph (iv) to 6 RCNY 4-63(b)(2) to require that, when the price of the petroleum product is less for a cash purchase than other forms of purchase, the mandated road sign and all other curb signs advertising the sale of gasoline and diesel motor fuel must display the total selling price per gallon with cash, debit card, credit card or other form of payment for each grade of the petroleum product offered for sale.

The rule amends subparagraph (ii) of section 4-63(b)(5) to require that the minimum type size used on the mandated road sign is at least 430 points to ensure that the price and other information can be read by motorists.

column5: denote mandatory requirements and may be used interchangeably in the rules of this department, unless otherwise specified or unless the context clearly indicates otherwise.

column2: Subdivision (b) of section 4-63 of subchapter E of Chapter 4 of Title 6 of the rules of the City of New York is amended to read as follows:

column1: (b) Required curb sign and other [Signs] signs not located on dispensing equipment.
(1) [Any sign, poster or placard used to display or refer to the price per gallon or used to advertise &ldquo
column5: or terms of like import, of petroleum products, including gasoline and diesel motor fuel, other than that used on a dispensing device, shall have a maximum size including the size of any frame, of 3 feet by 4 feet.]&nbsp
column6: Every location at which gasoline or diesel motor fuel is sold or offered for sale must maintain a sign, poster or placard clearly visible to drivers of approaching motor vehicles with dimensions not less than 60 inches in width by 36 inches in height.

column1: (2) There shall be clearly displayed on [such] every sign, poster or [other display] placard used to display or refer to the price per gallon or used to advertise petroleum products, including gasoline and diesel motor fuel, other than that used on a dispensing device:

(i) On the upper portion of the sign, the name, trade name, brand, mark or symbol, and grade or quality classification of such product, or, if such products are sold without identification, such sign, placard or other display shall refer clearly to such products as unbranded
(ii) the total selling price per unit of measure at which such product is customarily sold at retail which for gasoline or diesel motor fuel shall be by gallon
(iii) in close proximity to the total selling price, the legend &ldquo

<u>(iv) when the total selling price of purchases made with cash is less than the total selling price for purchases made with credit card, debit card or other form of non-cash payment, the following words referring to method of payment listed in the following order from left to right: &ldquo
column10: Each grade </u><u>of the petroleum product</u> <u>must be listed on a separate line.&nbsp
column11: Following the grade name, from left to right, each line must list the applicable price per method of payment beneath the corresponding method of payment listed, &ldquo

column1: (3) The total number of signs, posters and placards used to advertise &ldquo
column5: or selling prices of gasoline and diesel motor fuel shall not exceed the number of vehicular traffic streets upon which the service station faces. For the purpose of this section, signs used on dispensing devices shall not be included in the number of signs permitted to be displayed and a sandwich or &ldquo
column7: sign, placard or poster shall be considered one sign.

column1: (4) Any sign, poster or placard shall be located within the building line of the service station.
(5) Letters and numbers on such signs shall conform to the following:

(i) All numbers referring to price shall be the same height, width and thickness except that where a tenth of a cent number is used, that number must be at least one half the size of the number to which it relates.

(ii) [All letters shall be of a height, width and thickness that is no greater than the size of the largest number on the sign, poster or placard referring to price.] Type size cannot be less than 430 points.

(iii) Identification of the gasoline or diesel motor fuel offered for sale and any non-numerical language distinguishing the total cash selling price from the total credit card, debit card or other form of non-cash payment selling price shall be in letters and numbers not less than one-half of the height, width and thickness of the numbers referring to price.

column1: City University of New York NYC Early Childhood Professional Development Institute

The seeks approval to enter into an agreement with City University of New York NYC Early Childhood Professional Development Institute (CUNY-PDI) to provide a range of services including trainings, professional development, research, web development, and materials focused on improving information available to teachers regarding early childhood education.

P.S. 140, The Eagle School, seeks approval to enter into an agreement with Bell Foundation, Inc. (Bell) to provide an expanded learning time program for students in ELA and Mathematics, and professional development to teachers to deepen content knowledge.

The Division of Academics, Performance and Support seeks approval to extend an agreement with NCIEA to provide programming and professional development to support the implementation of the local Measures of Student Learning requirement of the new teacher evaluation and development system.
National Center for the Improvement of Educational Assessment (NCIEA)

The Division of Academics, Performance and Support seeks approval to extend an agreement with NCIEA to provide programming and professional development to support the implementation of the local Measures of Student Learning requirement of the new teacher evaluation and development system.

column2: Support seeks approval to enter into an agreement with InfusionDev, Inc., to develop, host, and provide end-user support/maintenance of the iPlan web portal.&nbsp
column3: The iPlan web portal is used for publication, submission, monitoring and feedback related to the Comprehensive Educational Plan (CEP) and the School Comprehensive Educational Plan (SCEP) for NYC schools.

column1: Notice of Intent to Issue New Solicitations Not Included in FY 2014 Annual Contracting Plan and Schedule

NOTICE IS HEREBY GIVEN that the Mayor will be issuing the following solicitations not included in the FY 2014 Annual Contracting Plan and Schedule that is published pursuant to New York City Charter §
Nature of services sought: Design and construction management services for projects to be located within New York City and upstate.

20131008101,2013-10-15 00:00:00.000,2013-10-15 00:00:00.000,1,836,149,NULL,13,0,,NULL,NULL,Rules Relating to the Rebate for Owners of Certain Real Property Seriously Damaged by Hurricane Sandy,NULL,NULL,NULL,NULL,NULL,NULL,NULL,NULL,NULL,NULL,NULL,NULL,user,1,user,2013-10-08 09:50:25.963,2013-10-07 17:25:30.807,3-8-5,user,NULL,NULL,20131008101,NULL,NULL,NULL,4,NULL, &nbsp
column3: THE CITY OF NEW YORK DEPARTMENT OF FINANCE &nbsp
column17: Pursuant to the power vested in me as Commissioner of Finance by section 467-g(10) of the Real Property Tax Law, sections 389(b) and 1043 of the New York City Charter, and section 11-240(10) of the Administrative Code of the City of New York, I hereby promulgate the within Rules of the Commissioner of Finance Relating to the Rebate for Owners of Certain Real Property Seriously Damaged by Hurricane Sandy.&nbsp
column18: These rules were published in proposed form on August 28, 2013.&nbsp
column19: A hearing for public comment was held on October 1, 2013. No comments were received in writing or orally, prior to or during the public hearing.&nbsp
column381: On July 31, 2013, Chapter 250 of the Laws of 2013 was enacted, effective immediately, which added a new section 467-g to the Real Property Tax Law. In accordance with Chapter 250, Local Law 67 of 2013 (enacted on August 12, 2013 and deemed effective July&nbsp
column382: 31, 2013) added a new section 11-240 to the New York City Administrative Code to grant a rebate of real property taxes to owners of certain real property seriously damaged by Hurricane Sandy. &nbsp
column383: Section 11-240 provides a rebate of real property taxes for any tax lot in the City that contained property on which there is a building that the Department of Buildings has determined to be seriously damaged and unsafe to enter or occupy or completely demolished as a result of the effects of Hurricane Sandy. &nbsp
column384: The law provides that the rebate be paid to the owner who owned the building on October 30, 2012.&nbsp
column385: Because many of these property owners may have been forced to relocate, the Department of Finance anticipates that some of the rebate checks that are mailed to such owners will not be received and thus not cashed or deposited. &nbsp
column386: In order to ensure that the best effort is made to provide the benefit of the rebate in the most efficient way to such owners, these rules authorize the Commissioner of Finance to credit the amount of the rebate to real property taxes and real property-related charges imposed on the real property where the rebate applies.&nbsp
column387: The credit will be made if the rebate check is not cashed or deposited within ninety days after the Department of Finance mailed the rebate check.&nbsp
column388: This credit is to be made only if the owner who is entitled to the rebate remains the owner of the property. In the cases in which it is presumed that a rebate check has not been received by the property owner, providing the credit in this manner will give the property owner the benefit intended by the State Legislature and the City Council. &nbsp
column394: denote mandatory requirements and may be used interchangeably in the rules of this department, unless otherwise specified or unless the context clearly indicates otherwise. &nbsp
column395: Section 1. Title 19 of the Rules of the City of New York is amended by adding a new Chapter 51 to read as follows: &nbsp
column397: Rules Relating to the Rebate for Owners of Certain Real Property Seriously Damaged by Hurricane Sandy &nbsp
column399: 51-01. Application of Hurricane Sandy rebate to past due, current and future real property taxes and real property-related charges. &nbsp
column400: With respect to the rebate that is authorized by Administrative Code &sect
column401: 11-240 for owners of certain real property seriously damaged by Hurricane Sandy, the Commissioner of Finance is authorized to enter a credit in the amount of such rebate to the account of such real property.&nbsp
column402: Such credit shall be applied toward the satisfaction of any real property taxes and real property-related charges that are due or are past due and those which may become due in the future.&nbsp
column403: The credit will be applied if the Commissioner of Finance determines: &nbsp
column404: by a date no earlier than ninety days after the Commissioner of Finance mailed a check for such rebate that such check has not been cashed or deposited, and &nbsp
column405: that the owner who is entitled to the rebate remains the owner of the real property to which the rebate applies. &nbsp

column12: Pursuant to the power vested in me as Commissioner of Finance by section 467-g(10) of the Real Property Tax Law, sections 389(b) and 1043 of the New York City Charter, and section 11-240(10) of the Administrative Code of the City of New York, I hereby promulgate the within Rules of the Commissioner of Finance Relating to the Rebate for Owners of Certain Real Property Seriously Damaged by Hurricane Sandy.&nbsp
column13: These rules were published in proposed form on August 28, 2013.&nbsp
column14: A hearing for public comment was held on October 1, 2013. No comments were received in writing or orally, prior to or during the public hearing.&nbsp

column1: On July 31, 2013, Chapter 250 of the Laws of 2013 was enacted, effective immediately, which added a new section 467-g to the Real Property Tax Law. In accordance with Chapter 250, Local Law 67 of 2013 (enacted on August 12, 2013 and deemed effective July&nbsp
column2: 31, 2013) added a new section 11-240 to the New York City Administrative Code to grant a rebate of real property taxes to owners of certain real property seriously damaged by Hurricane Sandy.

column1: Section 11-240 provides a rebate of real property taxes for any tax lot in the City that contained property on which there is a building that the Department of Buildings has determined to be seriously damaged and unsafe to enter or occupy or completely demolished as a result of the effects of Hurricane Sandy.
The law provides that the rebate be paid to the owner who owned the building on October 30, 2012.&nbsp
column2: Because many of these property owners may have been forced to relocate, the Department of Finance anticipates that some of the rebate checks that are mailed to such owners will not be received and thus not cashed or deposited.

column1: In order to ensure that the best effort is made to provide the benefit of the rebate in the most efficient way to such owners, these rules authorize the Commissioner of Finance to credit the amount of the rebate to real property taxes and real property-related charges imposed on the real property where the rebate applies.&nbsp
column2: The credit will be made if the rebate check is not cashed or deposited within ninety days after the Department of Finance mailed the rebate check.&nbsp
column3: This credit is to be made only if the owner who is entitled to the rebate remains the owner of the property. In the cases in which it is presumed that a rebate check has not been received by the property owner, providing the credit in this manner will give the property owner the benefit intended by the State Legislature and the City Council.

column5: denote mandatory requirements and may be used interchangeably in the rules of this department, unless otherwise specified or unless the context clearly indicates otherwise.

column1: Section 1. Title 19 of the Rules of the City of New York is amended by adding a new Chapter 51 to read as follows:
Rules Relating to the Rebate for Owners of Certain Real Property

column2: 51-01. Application of Hurricane Sandy rebate to past due, current and future real property taxes and real property-related charges.

column1: <u>With respect to the rebate that is authorized by Administrative Code &sect
column2: 11-240 for owners of certain real property seriously damaged by Hurricane Sandy, the Commissioner of Finance is authorized to enter a credit in the amount of such rebate to the account of such real property.&nbsp
column3: Such credit shall be applied toward the satisfaction of any real property taxes and real property-related charges that are due or are past due and those which may become due in the future.&nbsp
column4: The credit will be applied if the Commissioner of Finance determines:

column1: by a date no earlier than ninety days after the Commissioner of Finance mailed a check for such rebate that such check has not been cashed or deposited, and
that the owner who is entitled to the rebate remains the owner of the real property to which the rebate applies.
