20131009109,2013-10-11 00:00:00.000,2013-10-23 00:00:00.000,8,cpc,NULL,NULL,11,0,This Notice is part of a previously submitted ad. ,NULL,NULL,City Planning Commission DEIS NOTICE,NULL,NULL,NULL,2013-10-23 10:00:00.000,NULL,NULL,NULL,NULL,NULL,NULL,NULL,NULL,user,1,user,2013-10-17 16:34:37.063,2013-10-09 15:13:25.443,14-9-1,user,NULL,NULL,20131009109,NULL,NULL,NULL,1,NULL, CITY PLANNING COMMISSION HEARINGS NOTICE IS HEREBY GIVEN THAT RESOLUTIONS Have been adopted by the City Planning Commission Scheduling public hearings on the following matters to be held in Spector Hall, 22 Reade Street, New York, NY, on Wednesday, October 23, 2013 at 10:00 a.m. __________ &nbsp
column4: On Wednesday, October 23th, at 10:00 A.M., in Spector Hall, at the Department of City Planning, 22 Reade Street, in Lower Manhattan, a public hearing is being held by the City Planning Commission in conjunction with the above ULURP hearing to receive comments related to a Draft Environmental Impact Statement (DEIS) concerning a special permit, zoning map and text amendments and acquisition and disposition of city owned property for the Seaside Park and Community Arts Center in Brooklyn, Community District 13. The actions would facilitate an approximately 5,099 seat capacity amphitheater along the Coney Island Boardwalk.&nbsp
column6: The application also includes the acquisition of property by the City (Block 7071, Lots 27, 28, 30, 32, 34, 76, 130, 226 and 231) and disposition of City-owned properties (Block 7170, Lots 27, 28, 30, 32, 34, 76, 130, 142, 226 and 231).&nbsp
column8: Comments are requested on the DEIS and will be accepted until Monday, November 4, 2013. The lead agency is the Office of the Deputy Mayor for Economic Development. This hearing is being held pursuant to the State Environmental Quality Review Act (SEQRA) and City Environmental Quality Review (CEQR), CEQR No. 13DME014K. &nbsp

column1: Have been adopted by the City Planning Commission
Scheduling public hearings on the following matters to
be held in Spector Hall, 22 Reade Street, New York, NY,

<strong>On Wednesday, October 23th, at 10:00 A.M., in Spector Hall, at the Department of City Planning, 22 Reade Street, in Lower Manhattan, a public hearing is being held by the City Planning Commission in conjunction with the above ULURP hearing to receive comments related to a Draft Environmental Impact Statement (DEIS) concerning a special permit, zoning map and text amendments and acquisition and disposition of city owned property for the Seaside Park and Community Arts Center in Brooklyn, Community District 13. The actions would facilitate an approximately 5,099 seat capacity amphitheater along the Coney Island Boardwalk.&nbsp
column3: The application also includes the acquisition of property by the City (Block 7071, Lots 27, 28, 30, 32, 34, 76, 130, 226 and 231) and disposition of City-owned properties (Block 7170, Lots 27, 28, 30, 32, 34, 76, 130, 142, 226 and 231).&nbsp

column1: Comments are requested on the DEIS and will be accepted until Monday, November 4, 2013. The lead agency is the Office of the Deputy Mayor for Economic Development. This hearing is being held pursuant to the State Environmental Quality Review Act (SEQRA) and City Environmental Quality Review (CEQR), CEQR No. 13DME014K.

column2: Public Hearing will be held at the Department of Probation, 33 Beaver Street, 21st floor, Borough of Manhattan, Monday October 28, 2013 commencing at 11:30 A.M. on the following item:

column1: IN THE MATTER OF the proposed contract between the Department of Probation and the contractor listed below to provide the Mental Health/Juvenile Justice Diversion Project. The contractor&rsquo
column2: s PIN number and contract amount is indicated below. The term shall be from January 1, 2014 through December 31, 2014, and shall contain no option to renew.

column1: Jewish Child Care Association of New York
The proposed contractor will be awarded as a Required/Authorized Source, pursuant to Section 1-02(d)(2) of the Procurement Policy Board Rules.

column2: scope, specifications and terms and conditions will be available for public inspection at the Department of Probation, 33 Beaver Street, 21st Floor, New York, NY 10004, between the hours of 9:00 a.m. and 5:00 p.m. except holidays.&nbsp

column1: Anyone who wishes to speak at this public hearing should request to do so in writing.&nbsp
column2: The written request must be received by the Agency within 5 business days after publication of this notice.&nbsp
column3: Written requests to speak should be sent to Ms. Eileen Parfrey-Smith, Agency Chief Contracting Officer, 33 Beaver Street, 21st Floor, New York, NY 10004, acco@probation.nyc.gov.
column4: If the Department of Probation receives no written requests to speak within the prescribed time, the Department reserves the right not to conduct the public hearing.

20131011102,2013-10-18 00:00:00.000,2013-10-18 00:00:00.000,1,841,143,NULL,11,0,Needs to be published in City Record on October 18 in order to meet the 30 day notice requirement. ,NULL,NULL,Opportunity to comment on proposed New York City Department of Transportation rules relating to truck routes.,NULL,NULL,NULL,2013-11-19 15:00:00.000,NULL,NULL,NULL,NULL,NULL,NULL,NULL,NULL,user,1,user,2013-10-16 09:02:45.437,2013-10-15 16:36:32.440,20-10-5,user,NULL,NULL,20131011102,NULL,NULL,NULL,4,NULL, NOTICE OF PUBLIC HEARING &nbsp
column11: Opportunity to comment on proposed New York City Department of Transportation rules relating to truck routes. &nbsp
column199: Pursuant to the authority vested in the Commissioner of Transportation by Section 1043 of the New York City Charter and subdivision (a) of Section 2903 of the New York City Charter, and in accordance with the requirements of Section 1043 of the New York City Charter, NYCDOT proposes to amend subdivision (b) of Section 4-13 of Chapter 4 of Title 34 of the Official Compilation of the Rules of the City of New York, the Traffic Rules related to truck routes for the Borough of Queens. The proposed amendments were not included in the Agency&rsquo
column200: s regulatory agenda because the need for them was not foreseen at the time the agenda was finalized. &nbsp
column202: Instructions Written comments regarding the proposed rules may be sent to Dalila Hall, NYCDOT Queens Borough Commissioner, 120-55 Queens Boulevard, 2 nd Floor, Kew Gardens, NY 11424 on or before November 19, 2013 or may be submitted electronically to rules@dot.nyc.gov or to the NYC Rules web site at www.nyc.gov/nycrules . Individuals seeking to testify at the public hearing are requested to notify Queens Borough Commissioner Dalila Hall at the address stated above. Individuals who need a sign language interpreter or other accommodation for a disability at the hearing are asked to notify Queens Borough Commissioner Dalila Hall at the above address by November 12, 2013. Individuals interested in receiving comments may request them by writing to: New York City Department of Transportation, Record Access Office, 55 Water Street, 4 th Floor, New York City, NY 10041. &nbsp
column206: 1043 and 2903 (a) of the New York City Charter, the Commissioner of Transportation is authorized to promulgate rules regarding the conduct of vehicular and pedestrian traffic in the streets, squares, avenues, highways and parkways of the City as may be necessary. &nbsp
column209: Based upon recommendations from a truck study conducted in 2007 and a Maspeth Bypass Study which included truck origin and destination data, community meetings and local business and trucking industry requests for truck route changes, the Department of Transportation proposes to amend provisions of Title 34, Section 4-13 of the Rules of the City of New York in order to establish a more consistent designation of truck routes in the Borough of Queens.&nbsp
column210: Specifically, the proposed rule: Changes the designation of: 55 th Drive, 56 th Terrace, Flushing Avenue, Fresh Pond Road, Grand Avenue, Maspeth Avenue, and Page Place to Local Truck Routes. Dedesignates parts of Flushing Avenue, Fresh Pond Road and Grand Avenue as Local Truck Routes. &nbsp
column211: New matter in the following rule is underlined, and deleted material is in brackets. &nbsp
column215: denote mandatory requirements and may be used interchangeably in the rules of this department, unless otherwise specified or unless the context clearly indicates otherwise. &nbsp
column216: Paragraph (2) of subdivision (b) of section 4-13 of Chapter 4 of Title 34 of the Rules of the City of New York is amended by adding, in alphabetical order, new entries for 55 th Drive, 56 th Terrace, Maspeth Avenue, and Page Place
column217: and by deleting the entries for Flushing Avenue, Fresh Pond Road and Grand Avenue. The amendments read as follows: &nbsp

column10: Opportunity to comment on proposed New York City Department of Transportation rules relating to truck routes.

column1: Pursuant to the authority vested in the Commissioner of Transportation by Section 1043 of the New York City Charter and subdivision (a) of Section 2903 of the New York City Charter, and in accordance with the requirements of Section 1043 of the New York City Charter, NYCDOT proposes to amend subdivision (b) of Section 4-13 of Chapter 4 of Title 34 of the Official Compilation of the Rules of the City of New York, the Traffic Rules related to truck routes for the Borough of Queens. The proposed amendments were not included in the Agency&rsquo
column2: s regulatory agenda because the need for them was not foreseen at the time the agenda was finalized.

column1: Written comments regarding the proposed rules may be sent to Dalila Hall, NYCDOT Queens Borough Commissioner, 120-55 Queens Boulevard, 2nd Floor, Kew Gardens, NY 11424 on or before November 19, 2013 or may be submitted electronically to rules@dot.nyc.gov or to the NYC Rules web site at www.nyc.gov/nycrules .
Individuals seeking to testify at the public hearing are requested to notify Queens Borough Commissioner Dalila Hall at the address stated above.

Individuals who need a sign language interpreter or other accommodation for a disability at the hearing are asked to notify Queens Borough Commissioner Dalila Hall at the above address by November 12, 2013.
Individuals interested in receiving comments may request them by writing to: New York City Department of Transportation, Record Access Office, 55 Water Street, 4th Floor, New York City, NY 10041.

column3: 1043 and 2903 (a) of the New York City Charter, the Commissioner of Transportation is authorized to promulgate rules regarding the conduct of vehicular and pedestrian traffic in the streets, squares, avenues, highways and parkways of the City as may be necessary.

column1: Based upon recommendations from a truck study conducted in 2007 and a Maspeth Bypass Study which included truck origin and destination data, community meetings and local business and trucking industry requests for truck route changes, the Department of Transportation proposes to amend provisions of Title 34, Section 4-13 of the Rules of the City of New York in order to establish a more consistent designation of truck routes in the Borough of Queens.&nbsp
Changes the designation of: 55th Drive, 56th Terrace, Flushing Avenue, Fresh Pond Road, Grand Avenue, Maspeth Avenue, and Page Place to Local Truck Routes.
Dedesignates parts of Flushing Avenue, Fresh Pond Road and Grand Avenue as Local Truck Routes.
New matter in the following rule is underlined, and deleted material is in brackets.

column4: denote mandatory requirements and may be used interchangeably in the rules of this department, unless otherwise specified or unless the context clearly indicates otherwise.

column1: Paragraph (2) of subdivision (b) of section 4-13 of Chapter 4 of Title 34 of the Rules of the City of New York is amended by adding, in alphabetical order, new entries for 55<sup>th</sup> Drive, 56<sup>th</sup> Terrace, Maspeth Avenue, and Page Place
column2: and by deleting the entries for Flushing Avenue, Fresh Pond Road and Grand Avenue. The amendments read as follows:

column3: Pursuant to the power vested in me as Commissioner of Finance by sections 237 and 1642-a of the Vehicle and Traffic Law, sections 389(b) and 1043 of the New York City Charter, and section 19-203 of the Administrative Code of the City of New York, I hereby promulgate the within Rules of the Commissioner of Finance Relating to Intercity Bus Permit System.&nbsp
column4: These rules were published in proposed form on August 28, 2013.&nbsp
column5: A hearing for public comment was held on October 3, 2013. &nbsp
column359: The intercity bus industry has grown significantly over the last fifteen years. While intercity buses provide a useful service, their on-street operations can cause serious disruption to the local traffic network and risks to public safety. In certain communities within the City, the proliferation of these buses has led to an increase in traffic and sidewalk congestion
column360: a higher concentration of on-street bus parking, double parking or blocking of travel lanes
column361: and the creation of traffic and safety concerns for drivers, travelers, pedestrians and residents. &nbsp
column362: In an effort to help address these concerns, New York State adopted Vehicle and Traffic Law (VTL) Section 1642-a, which authorized the City to establish an intercity bus permit system inclusive of a schedule of fines or civil penalties for violations of rules related to the system. The Parking Violations Bureau (PVB), a part of the Department of Finance (DOF), is authorized to adjudicate violations of the DOT intercity bus permit system rules pursuant to Section 1642-a and Article 2-B of the VTL.&nbsp
column364: On April 10, 2013, the Mayor issued a letter designating the DOT to promulgate rules to implement and enforce the intercity bus permit system, and DOT has subsequently promulgated such rules (the &ldquo
column365: DOT intercity bus permit system rules&rdquo
column368: 4-01 and 4-10. The Mayor also designated the DOF and the ECB to promulgate rules setting forth fines or civil penalties for violations of the DOT intercity bus permit system rules. &nbsp
column369: In coordination with the DOT and the New York City Police Department (NYPD), both DOF and ECB intend to establish penalty schedules for violations of the DOT intercity bus permit system rules as part of a coordinated enforcement scheme.&nbsp
column370: In this rulemaking, DOF is amending 19 RCNY &sect
column371: 39-05 to add civil penalties for such DOT violations returnable to the PVB. Violations of such enforcement codes will result in a civil penalty of $500 for each violation.&nbsp
column372: It is anticipated that in a separate rulemaking, ECB will amend its DOT penalty schedule to include enforcement codes resulting in a civil penalty for first violations and enhanced penalties for repeat violators of the DOT intercity bus permit system rules, including violators of the DOF enforcement codes.&nbsp
column374: Violations of the DOT Intercity Bus Permit System Rules &nbsp
column375: These amendments to the DOT penalty schedule for offenses adjudicated at PVB involve the following violations of the DOT intercity bus permit system rules: &nbsp
column377: Unauthorized passenger pickup or discharge in violation of 34 RCNY &sect
column378: 4-10(c)(1) The intent of implementing an intercity bus permit system is to ensure that intercity bus operators utilizing the City&rsquo
column379: s curb space inform the DOT of their intended operations, and, once approved for such operations, adhere to permit requirements. In applying for a permit, bus operators will provide DOT with important information related to overall bus operations within the City necessary for administration of the program. &nbsp
column381: Failure of an intercity bus permit holder to prominently display a copy of an intercity bus permit in violation of 34 RCNY &sect
column382: 4-10(d)(7)(ii) The prominent display of a copy of the intercity bus permit is necessary to assure that enforcement officers are easily able to identify buses with valid authorization to utilize the City&rsquo
column385: Failure of an intercity bus permit holder to properly display the operator&rsquo
column386: s name, address and telephone number in violation of 34 RCNY &sect
column388: s name, address, and telephone number must be affixed in characters at least five inches high on both sides of the vehicle, with such display being in a color contrasting with that of the vehicle and placed approximately midway vertically on doors or side panels. The operator&rsquo
column389: s name, address, and telephone number are necessary to ensure that enforcement officers are easily able to identify buses with valid authorization to utilize the City&rsquo
column392: Unlawful stopping or standing in an assigned on-street bus stop location except when actively engaged in the pick-up or discharge of passengers by an intercity bus permit holder in violation of 34 RCNY &sect
column393: 4-10(d)(7)(v) Intercity bus permits are for the temporary utilization of curb space by approved bus operators in order to expeditiously pick up or discharge passengers. This code is necessary to ensure that permittees do not park or stand their vehicles in curb space and thereby create layover spaces in bus stops not intended for longer-term stops. &nbsp
column395: Altering an intercity bus permit in violation of 34 RCNY &sect
column396: 4-10(d)(7)(vi) Prohibiting the alteration of an intercity bus permit is necessary to ensure that enforcement officers have the ability to easily determine whether permittees are adhering to permit requirements.&nbsp

column1: Pursuant to the power vested in me as Commissioner of Finance by sections 237 and 1642-a of the Vehicle and Traffic Law, sections 389(b) and 1043 of the New York City Charter, and section 19-203 of the Administrative Code of the City of New York, I hereby promulgate the within Rules of the Commissioner of Finance Relating to Intercity Bus Permit System.&nbsp
column2: These rules were published in proposed form on August 28, 2013.&nbsp
column3: A hearing for public comment was held on October 3, 2013.

column1: The intercity bus industry has grown significantly over the last fifteen years. While intercity buses provide a useful service, their on-street operations can cause serious disruption to the local traffic network and risks to public safety. In certain communities within the City, the proliferation of these buses has led to an increase in traffic and sidewalk congestion
column2: a higher concentration of on-street bus parking, double parking or blocking of travel lanes
column3: and the creation of traffic and safety concerns for drivers, travelers, pedestrians and residents.

column1: In an effort to help address these concerns, New York State adopted Vehicle and Traffic Law (VTL) Section 1642-a, which authorized the City to establish an intercity bus permit system inclusive of a schedule of fines or civil penalties for violations of rules related to the system. The Parking Violations Bureau (PVB), a part of the Department of Finance (DOF), is authorized to adjudicate violations of the DOT intercity bus permit system rules pursuant to Section 1642-a and Article 2-B of the VTL.&nbsp

On April 10, 2013, the Mayor issued a letter designating the DOT to promulgate rules to implement and enforce the intercity bus permit system, and DOT has subsequently promulgated such rules (the &ldquo
column2: DOT intercity bus permit system rules&rdquo
column5: 4-01 and 4-10. The Mayor also designated the DOF and the ECB to promulgate rules setting forth fines or civil penalties for violations of the DOT intercity bus permit system rules.

column1: In coordination with the DOT and the New York City Police Department (NYPD), both DOF and ECB intend to establish penalty schedules for violations of the DOT intercity bus permit system rules as part of a coordinated enforcement scheme.&nbsp
column2: In this rulemaking, DOF is amending 19 RCNY &sect
column3: 39-05 to add civil penalties for such DOT violations returnable to the PVB. Violations of such enforcement codes will result in a civil penalty of $500 for each violation.&nbsp
column4: It is anticipated that in a separate rulemaking, ECB will amend its DOT penalty schedule to include enforcement codes resulting in a civil penalty for first violations and enhanced penalties for repeat violators of the DOT intercity bus permit system rules, including violators of the DOF enforcement codes.&nbsp

These amendments to the DOT penalty schedule for offenses adjudicated at PVB involve the following violations of the DOT intercity bus permit system rules:
<u>Unauthorized passenger pickup or discharge in violation of 34 RCNY &sect
The intent of implementing an intercity bus permit system is to ensure that intercity bus operators utilizing the City&rsquo
column2: s curb space inform the DOT of their intended operations, and, once approved for such operations, adhere to permit requirements. In applying for a permit, bus operators will provide DOT with important information related to overall bus operations within the City necessary for administration of the program.

column1: <u>Failure of an intercity bus permit holder to prominently display a copy of an intercity bus permit in violation of 34 RCNY &sect
The prominent display of a copy of the intercity bus permit is necessary to assure that enforcement officers are easily able to identify buses with valid authorization to utilize the City&rsquo

s name, address, and telephone number must be affixed in characters at least five inches high on both sides of the vehicle, with such display being in a color contrasting with that of the vehicle and placed approximately midway vertically on doors or side panels. The operator&rsquo

Intercity bus permits are for the temporary utilization of curb space by approved bus operators in order to expeditiously pick up or discharge passengers. This code is necessary to ensure that permittees do not park or stand their vehicles in curb space and thereby create layover spaces in bus stops not intended for longer-term stops.
<u>Altering an intercity bus permit in violation of 34 RCNY &sect

column2: New York City Department of Finance &nbsp
column4: Notice of Public Hearing and Opportunity to Comment on Proposed Rules &nbsp
column6: The Department of Finance (DOF) is proposing to amend its Rules Relating to Parking Violations to add a new section relating to photo speed monitoring systems for school zones. The new section adds penalties for violations of speed restrictions in school speed zones, establishes requirements for the notice of liability, and authorizes the Parking Violations Bureau to adjudicate violations. &nbsp
column7: When and where is the Hearing?&nbsp
column8: DOF will hold a public hearing on the proposed rule. The public hearing will take place at 1:00 P.M. on November 21, 2013. The hearing will be in the DOF hearing room at 345 Adams Street, 3 rd Floor, Brooklyn, New York 11201. &nbsp
column9: How do I comment on the proposed rules?&nbsp
column10: Anyone can comment on the proposed rules by: &nbsp
column12: You can submit comments to DOF through the NYC Rules Web site at http://rules.cityofnewyork.us . &nbsp
column14: You can email written comments to daumanr@finance.nyc.gov. &nbsp
column16: You can mail written comments to NYC Department of Finance, Legal Affairs Division, 345 Adams Street, 3 rd Floor, Brooklyn, N.Y. 11201, Attn: Robert Dauman. &nbsp
column17: Fax. You can fax written comments to NYC Department of Finance, Attn: Robert Dauman, (718) 403-3650. &nbsp
column19: Anyone who wants to comment on the proposed rule at the public hearing must sign up to speak.&nbsp
column20: You can sign up before the hearing by calling Joan Best at (718) 403-3669.&nbsp
column21: You can also sign up in the hearing room before the hearing begins on November 21, 2013 at 1:00 P.M.&nbsp
column22: You can speak for up to three minutes. &nbsp
column23: Is there a deadline to submit written comments?&nbsp
column24: The deadline to submit written comments is November 21, 2013. &nbsp
column25: Do you need assistance to participate in the Hearing? You must tell the Office of Legal Affairs if you need a reasonable accommodation of a disability at the Hearing. You must tell us if you need a sign language interpreter.&nbsp
column26: You can tell us by mail at the address given above.&nbsp
column27: You can tell us by e-mail at bestj@finance.nyc.gov . You may also tell us by telephone by calling Joan Best at (718) 403-3669.&nbsp
column28: You must tell us by November 7, 2013. &nbsp
column29: Can I review the comments made on the proposed rules? You can review the comments made online on the proposed rules by going to the website at http://rules.cityofnewyork.us/ . A few days after the hearing, a transcript of the hearing and copies of the written comments will be available to the public at the Legal Affairs Division. &nbsp
column30: What authorizes DOF to make this rule? Sections 389(b) and 1043 of the City Charter and section 1180-b of the Vehicle and Traffic Law authorize DOF to make this proposed rule.&nbsp
column31: This proposed rule was not included in DOF&rsquo
column32: s regulatory agenda for this Fiscal Year because it was not contemplated when DOF published the agenda. &nbsp
column33: Where can I find the DOF&rsquo
column36: s rules are in Title 19 of the Rules of the City of New York. &nbsp
column37: What rules govern the rulemaking process? DOF must meet the requirements of Section 1043 of the City Charter when creating or changing rules. This notice is made according to the requirements of Section 1043 of the City Charter. &nbsp
column38: Statement of Basis and Purpose of Proposed Rule &nbsp
column39: New York State has adopted Vehicle and Traffic Law (VTL) Section 1180-b, effective August 30, 2013, which authorizes the City to establish a demonstration program implementing photo speed violation monitoring systems to record maximum speed limit violations in school speed zones. Subdivision (e) of VTL Section 1180-b authorizes the Parking Violations Bureau (PVB), a division of the New York City Department of Finance (DOF), to promulgate a schedule of fines and penalties for such violations. Subdivision (g) establishes requirements for the notice of liability.&nbsp
column40: Subdivision (h) authorizes the PVB to adjudicate violations under Section 1180-b.&nbsp
column42: Speeding violations are often a significant factor in accidents which result in death or injury. Under VTL Section 1180-b, vehicle operators who exceed the speed limit in school zones and who are recorded by a photo speed violation monitoring system will receive a summons for the violation. VTL Section 1180-b enables the City to use technology to improve the safety and quality of life of motorists and pedestrians by reducing speeding in school zones.&nbsp
column44: The New York City Department of Transportation (DOT) will implement the demonstration program.&nbsp
column45: DOT will maintain the photo speed violation monitoring systems, send notices of liability to motorists, and transmit information relating to violations to DOF.&nbsp
column46: The proposed amendment establishes penalties for such violations, provides requirements for the notice of liability, and authorizes the PVB to adjudicate allegations of liability. &nbsp
column48: s authority for the proposed rule is found in sections 389(b) and 1043 of the New York City Charter and section 1180-b of the Vehicle and Traffic Law. &nbsp
column50: New material is underlined. [Deleted material is in brackets.] &nbsp
column55: denote mandatory requirements and may be used interchangeably in the rules of this department, unless otherwise specified or unless the context clearly indicates otherwise. &nbsp
column57: Proposed Amendment to Rules Relating to Photo Speed Violation Monitoring Systems &nbsp
column58: Section 1. It is proposed that a new section 39-21 be added to Chapter 39 of Title 19 of the Rules of the City of New York to read as follows:&nbsp
column64: (a) Liability. A vehicle owner who is liable for a violation pursuant to &sect
column65: 1180-b of the Vehicle and Traffic Law will be liable for a penalty of $50.00 for each such violation. &nbsp
column66: (b) Additional penalties. If the owner fails to make payment or contest the liability within thirty days after the mailing of the notice of liability, an additional penalty of $25.00 may be assessed pursuant to subdivision (e) of &sect
column67: 1180-b of the Vehicle and Traffic Law . &nbsp
column68: (c) Notice of liability. The notice of liability must be in accordance with the requirements of subdivision (g) of &sect
column69: 1180-b of the Vehicle and Traffic Law and in such form and substance as prescribed by the director of the New York City Parking Violations Bureau. &nbsp
column70: (d) Administrative law judges. The administrative law judges for the adjudication of parking violations appointed by the Commissioner of the New York City Department of Transportation or the Commissioner of the New York City Department of Finance will preside at hearings for the adjudication of allegations of liability in accordance with subdivision (h) of &sect
column71: 1180-b of the Vehicle and Traffic Law . &nbsp
column72: (e) Effective date. This section will remain in effect for as long as &sect
column73: 1180-b of the Vehicle and Traffic Law shall remain in effect.&nbsp

column1: Notice of Public Hearing and Opportunity to Comment on Proposed Rules

column2: The Department of Finance (DOF) is proposing to amend its Rules Relating to Parking Violations to add a new section relating to photo speed monitoring systems for school zones. The new section adds penalties for violations of speed restrictions in school speed zones, establishes requirements for the notice of liability, and authorizes the Parking Violations Bureau to adjudicate violations.

DOF will hold a public hearing on the proposed rule. The public hearing will take place at 1:00 P.M. on November 21, 2013. The hearing will be in the DOF hearing room at 345 Adams Street, 3rd Floor, Brooklyn, New York 11201.

column1: <strong>How do I comment on the proposed rules?&nbsp
column2: Anyone can comment on the proposed rules by:
You can submit comments to DOF through the NYC Rules Web site at http://rules.cityofnewyork.us.
You can email written comments to daumanr@finance.nyc.gov.
You can mail written comments to NYC Department of Finance, Legal Affairs Division, 345 Adams Street, 3rd Floor, Brooklyn, N.Y. 11201, Attn: Robert Dauman.

column1: Fax. You can fax written comments to NYC Department of Finance, Attn: Robert Dauman, (718) 403-3650.

column2: Anyone who wants to comment on the proposed rule at the public hearing must sign up to speak.
column3: You can sign up before the hearing by calling Joan Best at (718) 403-3669.&nbsp
column4: You can also sign up in the hearing room before the hearing begins on November 21, 2013 at 1:00 P.M.&nbsp
column5: You can speak for up to three minutes.

column1: <strong>Is there a deadline to submit written comments?&nbsp
column2: The deadline to submit written comments is November 21, 2013.

column1: Do you need assistance to participate in the Hearing? You must tell the Office of Legal Affairs if you need a reasonable accommodation of a disability at the Hearing. You must tell us if you need a sign language interpreter.
column2: You can tell us by mail at the address given above.&nbsp
column3: You can tell us by e-mail at bestj@finance.nyc.gov. You may also tell us by telephone by calling Joan Best at (718) 403-3669.
column4: You must tell us by November 7, 2013.

column1: Can I review the comments made on the proposed rules? You can review the comments made online on the proposed rules by going to the website at http://rules.cityofnewyork.us/. A few days after the hearing, a transcript of the hearing and copies of the written comments will be available to the public at the Legal Affairs Division.
What authorizes DOF to make this rule? Sections 389(b) and 1043 of the City Charter and section 1180-b of the Vehicle and Traffic Law authorize DOF to make this proposed rule.
column2: This proposed rule was not included in DOF&rsquo
column3: s regulatory agenda for this Fiscal Year because it was not contemplated when DOF published the agenda.

column4: s rules are in Title 19 of the Rules of the City of New York.

column1: What rules govern the rulemaking process? DOF must meet the requirements of Section 1043 of the City Charter when creating or changing rules. This notice is made according to the requirements of Section 1043 of the City Charter.
Statement of Basis and Purpose of Proposed Rule

New York State has adopted Vehicle and Traffic Law (VTL) Section 1180-b, effective August 30, 2013, which authorizes the City to establish a demonstration program implementing photo speed violation monitoring systems to record maximum speed limit violations in school speed zones. Subdivision (e) of VTL Section 1180-b authorizes the Parking Violations Bureau (PVB), a division of the New York City Department of Finance (DOF), to promulgate a schedule of fines and penalties for such violations. Subdivision (g) establishes requirements for the notice of liability.&nbsp
column2: Subdivision (h) authorizes the PVB to adjudicate violations under Section 1180-b.&nbsp

column1: Speeding violations are often a significant factor in accidents which result in death or injury. Under VTL Section 1180-b, vehicle operators who exceed the speed limit in school zones and who are recorded by a photo speed violation monitoring system will receive a summons for the violation. VTL Section 1180-b enables the City to use technology to improve the safety and quality of life of motorists and pedestrians by reducing speeding in school zones.&nbsp
The New York City Department of Transportation (DOT) will implement the demonstration program.&nbsp
column2: DOT will maintain the photo speed violation monitoring systems, send notices of liability to motorists, and transmit information relating to violations to DOF.&nbsp
column3: The proposed amendment establishes penalties for such violations, provides requirements for the notice of liability, and authorizes the PVB to adjudicate allegations of liability.

column2: s authority for the proposed rule is found in sections 389(b) and 1043 of the New York City Charter and section 1180-b of the Vehicle and Traffic Law.

column1: Proposed Amendment to Rules Relating to Photo Speed Violation Monitoring Systems
Section 1. It is proposed that a new section 39-21 be added to Chapter 39 of Title 19 of the Rules of the City of New York to read as follows:
<u>(a) Liability. A vehicle owner who is liable for a violation pursuant to </u><a href=""http://www.westlaw.com/Link/Document/FullText?findType=L&amp
column11: 1180-b of the Vehicle and Traffic Law will be liable for a penalty of $50.00 for each such violation.

column1: <u>(b) Additional penalties. If the owner fails to make payment or contest the liability within thirty days after the mailing of the notice of liability, an additional penalty of $25.00 may be assessed pursuant to subdivision (e) of </u><a href=""http://www.westlaw.com/Link/Document/FullText?findType=L&amp
column11: 1180-b of the Vehicle and Traffic Law.

column1: <u>(c) Notice of liability. The notice of liability must be in accordance with the requirements of subdivision (g) of </u><a href=""http://www.westlaw.com/Link/Document/FullText?findType=L&amp
column11: 1180-b of the Vehicle and Traffic Law and in such form and substance as prescribed by the director of the New York City Parking Violations Bureau.

column1: <u>(d) Administrative law judges. The administrative law judges for the adjudication of parking violations appointed by the Commissioner of the New York City Department of Transportation or the Commissioner of the New York City Department of Finance will preside at hearings for the adjudication of allegations of liability in accordance with subdivision (h) of </u><a href=""http://www.westlaw.com/Link/Document/FullText?findType=L&amp
column11: 1180-b of the Vehicle and Traffic Law.

column1: <u>(e) Effective date. This section will remain in effect for as long as </u><a href=""http://www.westlaw.com/Link/Document/FullText?findType=L&amp
column11: 1180-b of the Vehicle and Traffic Law shall remain in effect.

The public meeting is regarding a legally mandated environmental review for the installation of a comfort station at new Brighton as part of the Coney Island Beach and Boardwalk. ,NULL,NULL,Public Meeting on the Draft Scope of Work for the preparation of an Environmental Impact Statement for the Proposed New Brighton Comfort Station,NULL,NULL,NULL,2013-11-18 18:00:00.000,NULL,NULL,NULL,NULL,NULL,NULL,NULL,NULL,user,1,user,2013-10-16 10:56:59.523,2013-10-16 10:49:03.403,6-16-1,user,NULL,NULL,20131016103,NULL,NULL,NULL,1,NULL, Notice is hereby given that a Public Scoping Meeting will be held by the City of New York Department of Parks and Recreation (DPR), as lead agency for CEQR and SEQRA review, to accept comments on the Draft Scope of Work for the preparation of the Environmental Impact Statement for the proposed New Brighton Comfort Station. The Public Scoping Meeting will be held on Monday, November 18, 2013 from 6:00 p.m. to 8:00 p.m. at the Shorefront YM-YWHA of Brighton-Manhattan Beach, located at 3300 Coney Island Avenue in Brooklyn, New York, 11235. The preparation of this targeted EIS for the New Brighton Comfort Station was directed by a Brooklyn Supreme Court Justice sitting in Kings County in an order filed on August 27, 2013.&nbsp
column3: The proposed project entails the installation of a modular comfort station near the eastern end of the Brighton Beach Boardwalk, which is part of the larger Coney Island Beach and Boardwalk. The comfort station would be located approximately between Coney Island Avenue and Seacoast Terrace, in the neighborhood of Brighton Beach in Brooklyn. The new comfort station would replace a previously existing comfort station that was damaged by Superstorm Sandy in October 2012 and subsequently demolished. The replacement comfort station is on the waterfront side of the boardwalk and is partially constructed and would be located predominantly within the footprint of the previously existing comfort station. The installation of the proposed replacement comfort station would restore access to toilet and hand washing facilities to this portion of the Brighton Beach Boardwalk. &nbsp
column4: NYCDPR received permits for its proposed work efforts at Coney Island and Manhattan Beach, including this proposed comfort station, from the New York State Department of Environmental Conservation (NYSDEC) as per Article 34 of the Environmental Conservation Law (ECL) for new structures within the Coastal Erosion Hazard Area and Tidal Wetlands Permits as per Article 25 of the ECL. &nbsp
column5: Although the installation of the replacement comfort station is classified as a Type II action, an EIS for the New Brighton comfort station is being prepared to comply with the above-mentioned court order.&nbsp
column6: The EIS will comply with all procedures associated with that of an action classified as a Type I action pursuant to SEQRA/CEQR. There are no additional actions or approvals contemplated for this project.&nbsp
column8: A copy of the Draft Scope can be obtained online at http://www.nycgovparks.org or by contacting: &nbsp
column31: Colleen Alderson New York City Department of Parks and Recreation The Arsenal, Central Park 830 Fifth Avenue, Room 401 New York, New York 10065 Telephone: 212-360-3441 Fax: 212-360-3441 Email: colleen.alderson@parks.nyc.gov &nbsp
column32: Oral and written comments can be submitted at the Public Scoping Meeting.&nbsp
column33: Written comments can also be sent to the above address, fax number, or email address.&nbsp
column34: Written comments will be accepted by NYCDPR at the above address or by fax or e-mail through Monday, December 2, 2013. ",NULL,NULL,NULL,NULL,NULL,NULL,NULL,"

column1: Notice is hereby given that a Public Scoping Meeting will be held by the City of New York Department of Parks and Recreation (DPR), as lead agency for CEQR and SEQRA review, to accept comments on the Draft Scope of Work for the preparation of the Environmental Impact Statement for the proposed New Brighton Comfort Station. The Public Scoping Meeting will be held on Monday, November 18, 2013 from 6:00 p.m. to 8:00 p.m. at the Shorefront YM-YWHA of Brighton-Manhattan Beach, located at 3300 Coney Island Avenue in Brooklyn, New York, 11235.
The preparation of this targeted EIS for the New Brighton Comfort Station was directed by a Brooklyn Supreme Court Justice sitting in Kings County in an order filed on August 27, 2013.&nbsp

The proposed project entails the installation of a modular comfort station near the eastern end of the Brighton Beach Boardwalk, which is part of the larger Coney Island Beach and Boardwalk. The comfort station would be located approximately between Coney Island Avenue and Seacoast Terrace, in the neighborhood of Brighton Beach in Brooklyn. The new comfort station would replace a previously existing comfort station that was damaged by Superstorm Sandy in October 2012 and subsequently demolished. The replacement comfort station is on the waterfront side of the boardwalk and is partially constructed and would be located predominantly within the footprint of the previously existing comfort station. The installation of the proposed replacement comfort station would restore access to toilet and hand washing facilities to this portion of the Brighton Beach Boardwalk.

NYCDPR received permits for its proposed work efforts at Coney Island and Manhattan Beach, including this proposed comfort station, from the New York State Department of Environmental Conservation (NYSDEC) as per Article 34 of the Environmental Conservation Law (ECL) for new structures within the Coastal Erosion Hazard Area and Tidal Wetlands Permits as per Article 25 of the ECL.

Although the installation of the replacement comfort station is classified as a Type II action, an EIS for the New Brighton comfort station is being prepared to comply with the above-mentioned court order.&nbsp
column2: The EIS will comply with all procedures associated with that of an action classified as a Type I action pursuant to SEQRA/CEQR. There are no additional actions or approvals contemplated for this project.&nbsp

column1: A copy of the Draft Scope can be obtained online at http://www.nycgovparks.org or by contacting:
New York City Department of Parks and Recreation
Oral and written comments can be submitted at the Public Scoping Meeting.&nbsp
column2: Written comments can also be sent to the above address, fax number, or email address.&nbsp
column3: Written comments will be accepted by NYCDPR at the above address or by fax or e-mail through Monday, December 2, 2013.

column295: s Low Income Program, sponsors purchase City-owned land or vacant buildings and construct or rehabilitate multifamily buildings in order to create affordable rental housing.&nbsp
column296: Construction and permanent financing is provided through loans from private institutional lenders and from public sources including HPD, the New York City Housing Development Corporation, the State of New York, and the federal government.&nbsp
column297: Additional funding may also be provided from the syndication of low-income housing tax credits.&nbsp
column298: The newly constructed or rehabilitated buildings provide rental housing to low-income families. Subject to project underwriting, up to 20% of the units may be rented to formerly homeless families. &nbsp
column299: Under the proposed project, the City will sell the Disposition Area to Harlem Dowling Development Fund Company, Inc. (&quot
column301: ) for the nominal price of one dollar per tax lot.&nbsp
column302: The Sponsor will also deliver an enforcement note and mortgage for the remainder of the appraised value (&ldquo
column305: The Sponsor will then construct one building containing a total of 60 rental dwelling units and approximately 15,925 square feet of community facility space on the Disposition Area. &nbsp
column306: The Land Debt will be repayable out of resale or refinancing profits for a period of thirty (30) years following completion of construction. The remaining balance, if any, may be forgiven in the 30th year. &nbsp
column307: The appraisal and the proposed Land Disposition Agreement and Project Summary are available for public examination at the office of HPD, 100 Gold Street, Room 5-A1, New York, New York on business days during business hours. &nbsp

column1: Pursuant to Section 695(2)(b) of the General Municipal Law and Section 1802(6)(j) of the Charter, notice is hereby given that the Department of Housing Preservation and Development (&quot
column3: ) of the City of New York (&quot
column5: ) has proposed the sale of the following City-owned property (collectively, &quot

column2: s Low Income Program, sponsors purchase City-owned land or vacant buildings and construct or rehabilitate multifamily buildings in order to create affordable rental housing.&nbsp
column3: Construction and permanent financing is provided through loans from private institutional lenders and from public sources including HPD, the New York City Housing Development Corporation, the State of New York, and the federal government.&nbsp
column4: Additional funding may also be provided from the syndication of low-income housing tax credits.&nbsp
column5: The newly constructed or rehabilitated buildings provide rental housing to low-income families. Subject to project underwriting, up to 20% of the units may be rented to formerly homeless families.

column1: Under the proposed project, the City will sell the Disposition Area to Harlem Dowling Development Fund Company, Inc. (&quot
column3: ) for the nominal price of one dollar per tax lot.&nbsp
column4: The Sponsor will also deliver an enforcement note and mortgage for the remainder of the appraised value (&ldquo
column7: The Sponsor will then construct one building containing a total of 60 rental dwelling units and approximately 15,925 square feet of community facility space on the Disposition Area.

column1: The Land Debt will be repayable out of resale or refinancing profits for a period of thirty (30) years following completion of construction. The remaining balance, if any, may be forgiven in the 30th year.

The appraisal and the proposed Land Disposition Agreement and Project Summary are available for public examination at the office of HPD, 100 Gold Street, Room 5-A1, New York, New York on business days during business hours.

PLEASE TAKE NOTICE that a public hearing will be held on November 25, 2013 at Second Floor Conference Room, 22 Reade Street, Manhattan at 10:00 a.m., or as soon thereafter as the matter may be reached on the calendar, at which time and place those wishing to be heard will be given an opportunity to be heard concerning the proposed sale of the Disposition Area pursuant to Section 695(2)(b) of the General Municipal Law and Section 1802(6)(j) of the Charter.
Individuals requesting sign language interpreters should contact the Mayor&#39
column2: s Office Of Contract Services, Public Hearings Unit, 253 Broadway, Room 915, New York, New York 10007, (212) 788-7490, no later than five (5) business days prior to the public hearing.&nbsp

20131021102,2013-10-28 00:00:00.000,2013-10-28 00:00:00.000,1,030,140,NULL,13,0,,NULL,NULL,NOTICE OF COMPLETION OF A FINAL ENVIRONMENTAL IMPACT STATEMENT -CEQR No. 09DCP002K-,NULL,NULL,NULL,NULL,NULL,NULL,NULL,NULL,NULL,NULL,NULL,NULL,user,1,user,2013-10-21 16:03:35.207,2013-10-21 11:22:15.507,11-21-6,user,NULL,NULL,20131021102,NULL,NULL,NULL,5,NULL," NOTICE OF COMPLETION OF A FINAL ENVIRONMENTAL IMPACT STATEMENT &nbsp
column235: New York, New York 10007 SEQRA Classification: Unlisted&nbsp
column279: Contact Person Robert Dobruskin, Director (212) 720-3423 Environmental Assessment and Review Division New York City Department of City Planning &nbsp
column280: Pursuant to City Environmental Quality Review (CEQR), Mayoral Executive Order No. 91 of 1977, CEQR Rules of Procedure of 1991 and the regulations of Article 8 of the State Environmental Conservation Law, State Environmental Quality Review Act (SEQRA) as found in 6 NYCRR Part 617, a Final Environmental Impact Statement (FEIS) has been prepared for the action described below. &nbsp
column281: The Applicant, Forrest Lots, LLC, is requesting a zoning map amendment, a zoning text amendment, and changes to the city map (collectively, the &ldquo
column283: ) affecting an approximately 6 block area within the Bushwick neighborhood of Brooklyn, Community District 4. The affected area is generally bounded by Flushing Avenue, Evergreen Avenue, Melrose Street, Stanwix Street, Forrest Street, Garden Street, and Beaver Street. The Proposed Action would rezone all or portions of Blocks 3137, 3138, 3139, 3140, 3141 and 3152. The affected area is currently zoned M1-1 and M3-1, light and heavy manufacturing districts, respectively. The proposed zoning map amendment would rezone the area M1-2, R6A and R7A with selected C2-4 commercial overlays. The proposed zoning text amendment would establish the Inclusionary Housing program within the proposed R6A and R7A districts within the rezoning area. The City Map change would establish the section of Stanwix Street from Montieth Street to Forrest Street and the section of Noll Street between Evergreen Avenue and Stanwix Street as mapped streets. &nbsp
column284: The Proposed Action would facilitate a proposal by the Applicant to redevelop four sites with 54,182 square feet (sf) of local retail space and 977 dwelling units (DUs), of which 242 DUs would be affordable to low-to-moderate-income households, per the Inclusionary Housing regulations (47 units would be set aside for senior housing) by 2016. For environmental analysis purposes, the FEIS projects that on the Applicant&rsquo
column285: s sites the Proposed Action would result in a net increase of 54,182 sf of local retail space and 977 dwelling units (DUs), of which 195 DUs would be affordable to low-to-moderate-income households, per the Inclusionary Housing regulations. In addition, the Proposed Action could facilitate new development on four sites not under the applicant&rsquo
column287: On these properties, the Proposed Action could result in a net increase of 99 DUs, of which 20 DUs would be affordable per the Inclusionary Housing regulations, and 20,013 sf of local retail. In total, the Proposed Action is expected to result in development on eight (8) sites generating a net increase of approximately 1,076 DUs, of which 215 would be considered affordable, and 74,194 sf of local retail. &nbsp
column288: The Proposed Action includes (E) designations (E-315) for hazardous materials, noise, and air quality. The (E) designation is a mechanism that ensures no significant adverse impacts would result from a proposed action because of steps that would be undertaken prior to the development of a rezoned site. The (E) designation would ensure that these identified sites would not be developed unless necessary remedial measures are implemented. &nbsp
column289: The FEIS identifies potential significant adverse impacts related to open space, community facilities (elementary schools) and transportation (traffic). Measures to mitigate the community facilities and open space impacts were explored and evaluated in between the Draft and EIS in consultation with the New York City School Construction Authority (SCA), the New York City Department of Education (DOE), the New York City Department of Parks (DPR) and the lead agency, DCP. The FEIS identifies measures that would fully mitigate impacts for community facilities and traffic and partially mitigate open space impacts. Absent the implementation of the measures identified in the FEIS, the Proposed Action could have an unmitigated significant adverse impact on elementary schools. While the identified impact to open space could be partially mitigated with the measures identified in the FEIS, it would still constitute an unavoidable significant adverse impact on open space resources. As the significant adverse impact on open space would not be fully mitigated, the Proposed Action would result in an unavoidable adverse impact on open space. &nbsp
column290: The FEIS evaluates three alternatives to the proposed action: a No Action Alternative, a Lower Density Alternative, and a No Impact Alternative. &nbsp
column291: Copies of the FEIS are available for public inspection at the office of the undersigned.&nbsp
column292: The proposal involves actions by the City Planning Commission and Council of the City of New York pursuant to Uniform Land Use Review Procedures (ULURP).&nbsp
column293: A public hearing on the Draft Environmental Impact Statement (DEIS) was held on September 11, 2013.&nbsp
column294: Written comments on the DEIS were requested and were received by the Lead Agency until September 23, 2013.&nbsp
column295: The FEIS incorporates responses to the public comments received on the DEIS and additional analysis conducted subsequent to the completion of the DEIS.&nbsp

column1: NOTICE OF COMPLETION OF A FINAL ENVIRONMENTAL IMPACT STATEMENT
New York City Department of City Planning

Pursuant to City Environmental Quality Review (CEQR), Mayoral Executive Order No. 91 of 1977, CEQR Rules of Procedure of 1991 and the regulations of Article 8 of the State Environmental Conservation Law, State Environmental Quality Review Act (SEQRA) as found in 6 NYCRR Part 617, a Final Environmental Impact Statement (FEIS) has been prepared for the action described below.
The Applicant, Forrest Lots, LLC, is requesting a zoning map amendment, a zoning text amendment, and changes to the city map (collectively, the &ldquo
column3: ) affecting an approximately 6 block area within the Bushwick neighborhood of Brooklyn, Community District 4. The affected area is generally bounded by Flushing Avenue, Evergreen Avenue, Melrose Street, Stanwix Street, Forrest Street, Garden Street, and Beaver Street. The Proposed Action would rezone all or portions of Blocks 3137, 3138, 3139, 3140, 3141 and 3152. The affected area is currently zoned M1-1 and M3-1, light and heavy manufacturing districts, respectively. The proposed zoning map amendment would rezone the area M1-2, R6A and R7A with selected C2-4 commercial overlays. The proposed zoning text amendment would establish the Inclusionary Housing program within the proposed R6A and R7A districts within the rezoning area. The City Map change would establish the section of Stanwix Street from Montieth Street to Forrest Street and the section of Noll Street between Evergreen Avenue and Stanwix Street as mapped streets.

column1: The Proposed Action would facilitate a proposal by the Applicant to redevelop four sites with 54,182 square feet (sf) of local retail space and 977 dwelling units (DUs), of which 242 DUs would be affordable to low-to-moderate-income households, per the Inclusionary Housing regulations (47 units would be set aside for senior housing) by 2016. For environmental analysis purposes, the FEIS projects that on the Applicant&rsquo
column2: s sites the Proposed Action would result in a net increase of 54,182 sf of local retail space and 977 dwelling units (DUs), of which 195 DUs would be affordable to low-to-moderate-income households, per the Inclusionary Housing regulations. In addition, the Proposed Action could facilitate new development on four sites not under the applicant&rsquo
column4: On these properties, the Proposed Action could result in a net increase of 99 DUs, of which 20 DUs would be affordable per the Inclusionary Housing regulations, and 20,013 sf of local retail. In total, the Proposed Action is expected to result in development on eight (8) sites generating a net increase of approximately 1,076 DUs, of which 215 would be considered affordable, and 74,194 sf of local retail.

column1: The Proposed Action includes (E) designations (E-315) for hazardous materials, noise, and air quality. The (E) designation is a mechanism that ensures no significant adverse impacts would result from a proposed action because of steps that would be undertaken prior to the development of a rezoned site. The (E) designation would ensure that these identified sites would not be developed unless necessary remedial measures are implemented.

The FEIS identifies potential significant adverse impacts related to open space, community facilities (elementary schools) and transportation (traffic). Measures to mitigate the community facilities and open space impacts were explored and evaluated in between the Draft and EIS in consultation with the New York City School Construction Authority (SCA), the New York City Department of Education (DOE), the New York City Department of Parks (DPR) and the lead agency, DCP. The FEIS identifies measures that would fully mitigate impacts for community facilities and traffic and partially mitigate open space impacts. Absent the implementation of the measures identified in the FEIS, the Proposed Action could have an unmitigated significant adverse impact on elementary schools. While the identified impact to open space could be partially mitigated with the measures identified in the FEIS, it would still constitute an unavoidable significant adverse impact on open space resources. As the significant adverse impact on open space would not be fully mitigated, the Proposed Action would result in an unavoidable adverse impact on open space.
The FEIS evaluates three alternatives to the proposed action: a No Action Alternative, a Lower Density Alternative, and a No Impact Alternative.
Copies of the FEIS are available for public inspection at the office of the undersigned.&nbsp
column2: The proposal involves actions by the City Planning Commission and Council of the City of New York pursuant to Uniform Land Use Review Procedures (ULURP).&nbsp
column3: A public hearing on the Draft Environmental Impact Statement (DEIS) was held on September 11, 2013.&nbsp
column4: Written comments on the DEIS were requested and were received by the Lead Agency until September 23, 2013.&nbsp
column5: The FEIS incorporates responses to the public comments received on the DEIS and additional analysis conducted subsequent to the completion of the DEIS.&nbsp

column2: INTENT TO AWARD as a concession a Sole Source License Agreement to Bike the Greenway LLC (&ldquo
column4: ) whose address is 140 West 30 th Street, Suite 5E, New York, 10001, the installation, operation and maintenance of a bike rental station at Battery Park, approximately across from 17 State Street, Manhattan. The Agreement will commence upon Notice to Proceed. Compensation to the City will be as follows: For each Operating Year, except Operating Year 1, compensation will be the greater of a $17,000 minimum annual fee or 12.5% of Gross Receipts between $100,000 and $149,999, 13.50% of Gross Receipts between $150,000 and $199,999 and 14.50% of Gross Receipts equal to or above $200,000. In Operating Year 1, which will only be a partial year, compensation will be the greater of $7,083.00 or 12.5% of Gross Receipts between $100,000 and $149,999, 13.50% of Gross Receipts between $150,000 and $199,999 and 14.50% of Gross Receipts equal to or above $200,000. Notwithstanding the foregoing, with respect to guided tours sold at Battery Park that originate at locations other than Battery Park, such sales shall not be included in Gross Receipts, and compensation to the City for these sales will instead be a separate fee of 2% of&nbsp
column6: s total receipts from such sales. &nbsp
column7: LOCATION: A draft copy of the license agreement may be reviewed or obtained at no cost, commencing October 31, 2013, through November 12, 2013, between the hours of 9am and 5pm, excluding weekends and holidays at the NYC Department of Parks and Recreation, located at 830 Fifth Avenue, Room 313, New York, NY 10065. &nbsp

column3: Notice is hereby given that, pursuant to Title 22 Section 625 of the NYC Administrative Code, the Industrial Business Zone Boundary Commission will hold a public hearing on Friday, November 8, 2013, commencing at 2:00 PM and concluding at 4:00 PM to receive comments related to the proposed boundaries for an Industrial Business Zone for the Ridgewood area of Queens and for an addition to the Industrial Business Zone in the Port Morris area of the Bronx.&nbsp
column4: The hearing will be held at 110 William Street, 4 th Floor, Conference Room 4A, New York, New York 10038.&nbsp
column5: Those wishing to be heard are encouraged to pre-register by contacting the Boundary Commission staff through email at: industrial@nycedc.com or can register on the date of the hearing&nbsp
column6: between the hours of 1:00 PM and 2:00 PM at 110 William Street, 4 th Floor.&nbsp
column7: To register in advance to testify in person, please email industrial@nycedc.com .&nbsp
column8: Please include your name, what business or group you are representing, and the IBZ for which you would like to testify. Maps of the proposed Industrial Business Zone boundaries for Ridgewood, Queens and Port Morris, Bronx are available for public review in this issue of the City Record and can be found at www.nycedc.com/ibz .&nbsp
column9: If you wish to view the proposed boundaries in hard copy or have additional questions, please contact staff through industrial@nycedc.com or call (212) 312-3982.&nbsp
column10: Members of the public may submit written or oral testimony regarding the proposed boundaries.&nbsp
column11: Written comments should be submitted to the Boundary Commission staff by emailing industrial@nycedc.com .&nbsp
column12: Written comments may be submitted until 5:00 PM on Friday, November 8, 2013.&nbsp

column1: New York City Industrial Business Zone Boundary Commission

Notice is hereby given that, pursuant to Title 22 Section 625 of the NYC Administrative Code, the Industrial Business Zone Boundary Commission will hold a public hearing on Friday, November 8, 2013, commencing at 2:00 PM and concluding at 4:00 PM to receive comments related to the proposed boundaries for an Industrial Business Zone for the Ridgewood area of Queens and for an addition to the Industrial Business Zone in the Port Morris area of the Bronx.&nbsp
column2: The hearing will be held at 110 William Street, 4<sup>th</sup> Floor, Conference Room 4A, New York, New York 10038.&nbsp
column3: Those wishing to be heard are encouraged to pre-register by contacting the Boundary Commission staff through email at: industrial@nycedc.com or can register on the date of the hearing
column4: between the hours of 1:00 PM and 2:00 PM at 110 William Street, 4<sup>th</sup> Floor.&nbsp
column5: To register in advance to testify in person, please email industrial@nycedc.com.
column6: Please include your name, what business or group you are representing, and the IBZ for which you would like to testify.

column1: Maps of the proposed Industrial Business Zone boundaries for Ridgewood, Queens and Port Morris, Bronx are available for public review in this issue of the City Record and can be found at www.nycedc.com/ibz.
column2: If you wish to view the proposed boundaries in hard copy or have additional questions, please contact staff through industrial@nycedc.com or call (212) 312-3982.
column3: Members of the public may submit written or oral testimony regarding the proposed boundaries.&nbsp
column4: Written comments should be submitted to the Boundary Commission staff by emailing industrial@nycedc.com.
column5: Written comments may be submitted until 5:00 PM on Friday, November 8, 2013.&nbsp

column1: As an M/W/DBE construction contractor, you can improve your ability to access credit.
Join us for the Money Matters Workshop where you will learn how to:
Find flexible financing such as NYCEDC&#39
Look at your projects from a cash flow perspective and determine the amount of money you need to borrow
Successfully market yourself to financial institutions
Monday Workshops and Thursday Technical Assistance Sessions
110 William Street Room 4AB, New York, NY 10038
These are all extremely important matters to your business growth and future success. We look forward to working with you.
Go to nycedc.com/moneymatters to fill out the application to attend the workshop and submit it by clicking the button at the end of the form or emailing it to John Rooney at mjrooney@nycedc.com.
Space is limited. Please RSVP today.

20131025103,2013-10-28 00:00:00.000,2013-11-01 00:00:00.000,5,068,123,NULL,13,0,Need to publish the notice for Concept Paper as soon as possible for release.,NULL,NULL,Respite Care Concept Paper,NULL,NULL,NULL,NULL,NULL,NULL,NULL,NULL,NULL,NULL,NULL,NULL,user,1,user,2013-10-25 11:00:17.717,2013-10-25 10:54:33.313,4-25-6 LATE NOTICE,user,NULL,NULL,20131025103,NULL,NULL,NULL,5,NULL, In advance of the release of a Request for Proposals (RFP), the New York City Administration for Children&rsquo
column2: s Services (ACS) is posting a concept paper setting forth the services that potential, qualified vendors will be able to provide for Respite Care services to youth who have come into contact with, or are at risk of coming into contact with the juvenile justice system. Through the RFP, ACS seeks to develop a new program model that emphasizes the engagement of at-risk and vulnerable populations of youth within our continuum of care, and reinforces fundamental expectations of accountability for outcomes and child and family-centered practices. The concept paper will be posted on the ACS website, https://a068-aprodapp15.nyc.gov/rfponline/ under Business Opportunities - Concept Papers from November 2, 2013 to December 17, 2013. All comments in response to the concept paper should be in writing via e-mail to: respitcare@dfa.state.ny.us ",NULL,NULL,NULL,NULL,NULL,NULL,NULL,"

column1: In advance of the release of a Request for Proposals (RFP), the New York City Administration for Children&rsquo
column2: s Services (ACS) is posting a concept paper setting forth the services that potential, qualified vendors will be able to provide for Respite Care services to youth who have come into contact with, or are at risk of coming into contact with the juvenile justice system. Through the RFP, ACS seeks to develop a new program model that emphasizes the engagement of at-risk and vulnerable populations of youth within our continuum of care, and reinforces fundamental expectations of accountability for outcomes and child and family-centered practices.

column1: The concept paper will be posted on the ACS website, https://a068-aprodapp15.nyc.gov/rfponline/ under Business Opportunities - Concept Papers from November 2, 2013 to December 17, 2013. All comments in response to the concept paper should be in writing via e-mail to: respitcare@dfa.state.ny.us

20131025104,2013-10-29 00:00:00.000,2013-10-29 00:00:00.000,1,829,NULL,NULL,13,0,NULL,NULL,NULL,Notice of Promulgation of Rules,NULL,NULL,NULL,NULL,NULL,NULL,NULL,NULL,NULL,NULL,NULL,NULL,user,1,user,2013-10-25 11:52:40.047,2013-10-25 11:49:34.460,10-24-5,user,NULL,NULL,20131025104,NULL,NULL,NULL,4,NULL, Notice of Promulgation of Rules PURSUANT TO section 1043 of the New York City Charter and exercising the authority vested in the Business Integrity Commission by sections 1043(a) and 2101 of the New York City Charter, and by sections 16-504 and 16-519 of the Administrative Code, the Business Integrity Commission amends rules relating to maximum rates for removal of waste by a licensee. &nbsp
column2: Statement of Basis and Purpose of Final Rule &nbsp
column4: 2101 of the New York City Charter, the Business Integrity Commission (BIC) is authorized to regulate the trade waste industry and ensure businesses are able to operate in an honest and competitive environment free from the influences of organized crime and criminality.&nbsp
column5: BIC has the authority pursuant to &sect
column8: 16-519 of the Administrative Code to set by rule the maximum rates by weight and by volume that trade waste haulers can charge for the removal of putrescible and recyclable commercial waste. &nbsp
column10: 16-519 of the Administrative Code, these rule amendments are designed to ensure that licensed trade waste haulers subject to rate-setting by BIC are able to collect a fair and reasonable return to licensees for waste removal services provided to commercial establishments in New York City, while protecting those using these services from excessive or unreasonable charges. Rates were last adjusted in 2008. The rate change reflects an increase of approximately 15% over current rates and is based on an analysis of costs and revenues, and of inflation in the regulated portion of the industry.&nbsp
column11: Specifically, the amendments will require trade waste businesses to set rates at or below the following values:&nbsp
column12: $18.27 per cubic yard $11.98 per 100 lbs In addition, these rule amendments establish an administrative procedure to provide greater transparency, standardization and regularity in the rate-setting process, which does not currently exist and is of benefit to the regulated industry, their customers and BIC.&nbsp
column13: BIC will now conduct a formal review every odd year to ensure that rates are in line with changes and trends in the market. As rates are set also to preserve and protect the interests of commercial establishments, the proposed amendments will place the burden on haulers to demonstrate why the current rates should be changed.&nbsp
column22: denote mandatory requirement and may be used interchangeably in the text below, unless otherwise specified or unless the context clearly indicates otherwise. &nbsp
column25: Section 1. Subdivision (a) of section 5-02 of subchapter E of Chapter 1 of Title 17 of the Rules of the City of New York is amended to read as follows: &nbsp
column26: (a) A trade waste removal business shall not demand, charge, exact, or accept rates for the collection, removal, disposal, or recycling of trade waste greater than the following maximum rates: (1) [$15.89] $18.27 per cubic yard. (2) [$10.42] $11.98 per 100 pounds. (3) Exempt Waste. This subdivision shall not apply to the removal of construction and demolition debris, infectious medical waste, covered electronic equipment as defined in &sect
column27: 421 of chapter 16 of the Code, waste from grease interceptors as defined in &sect
column28: 19-119(a) of title 15 of the Rules of the City of New York and paper that is collected for the purpose of shredding or destruction by the licensee. &nbsp
column30: 2. Section 5-02 of subchapter E of Chapter 1 of Title 17 of the Rules of the City of New York is amended by adding new subdivisions (f) and (g) to read as follows: &nbsp
column31: (f) No later than October 31 of every odd-numbered year, the Commission will hold a public hearing on the maximum rates charged by a licensee for the collection, removal, disposal, or recycling of trade waste.&nbsp
column32: At least 30 days prior to the public hearing, the Commission will publish the date, time and location of the public hearing in the City Record and on the Commission website.&nbsp
column33: At the hearing, proponents of a change in the maximum rates may submit oral or written testimony.&nbsp
column34: The proponent of the rate change shall bear the burden of demonstrating, on an industry-wide basis, that existing rates are inconsistent with the standards for maximum rates set forth in &sect
column37: (g) In determining whether the maximum rates charged by licensees for the collection, removal, disposal, or recycling of trade waste will be adjusted, the Commission shall not be limited to evidence provided by proponents of a rate change pursuant subdivision (f) of this section and may consider any relevant factor affecting the trade waste industry or its customers, including but not limited to: &nbsp
column38: (1) The Producer Price Index (PPI), as published by the United States Department of Labor Bureau of Labor Statistics
column39: (2) Available data on the trade waste industry, including but not limited to: &nbsp
column62: (b) Regulated service operating revenues (revenue generated from waste removal services associated with rate-regulated portion of business)
column178: (3) Any other factor that may be relevant to assessing a fair and reasonable return to licensees and the protection of those using the services of such licensees from excessive or unreasonable charges. ",NULL,NULL,NULL,NULL,NULL,NULL,NULL,"

column1: PURSUANT TO section 1043 of the New York City Charter and exercising the authority vested in the Business Integrity Commission by sections 1043(a) and 2101 of the New York City Charter, and by sections 16-504 and 16-519 of the Administrative Code, the Business Integrity Commission amends rules relating to maximum rates for removal of waste by a licensee.
Statement of Basis and Purpose of Final Rule

column2: 2101 of the New York City Charter, the Business Integrity Commission (BIC) is authorized to regulate the trade waste industry and ensure businesses are able to operate in an honest and competitive environment free from the influences of organized crime and criminality.&nbsp
column3: BIC has the authority pursuant to &sect
column6: 16-519 of the Administrative Code to set by rule the maximum rates by weight and by volume that trade waste haulers can charge for the removal of putrescible and recyclable commercial waste.

column2: 16-519 of the Administrative Code, these rule amendments are designed to ensure that licensed trade waste haulers subject to rate-setting by BIC are able to collect a fair and reasonable return to licensees for waste removal services provided to commercial establishments in New York City, while protecting those using these services from excessive or unreasonable charges. Rates were last adjusted in 2008. The rate change reflects an increase of approximately 15% over current rates and is based on an analysis of costs and revenues, and of inflation in the regulated portion of the industry.&nbsp

column1: Specifically, the amendments will require trade waste businesses to set rates at or below the following values:&nbsp

In addition, these rule amendments establish an administrative procedure to provide greater transparency, standardization and regularity in the rate-setting process, which does not currently exist and is of benefit to the regulated industry, their customers and BIC.&nbsp
column2: BIC will now conduct a formal review every odd year to ensure that rates are in line with changes and trends in the market. As rates are set also to preserve and protect the interests of commercial establishments, the proposed amendments will place the burden on haulers to demonstrate why the current rates should be changed.&nbsp

column5: denote mandatory requirement and may be used interchangeably in the text below, unless otherwise specified or unless the context clearly indicates otherwise.

(a) A trade waste removal business shall not demand, charge, exact, or accept rates for the
collection, removal, disposal, or recycling of trade waste greater than the following maximum
(3) Exempt Waste. This subdivision shall not apply to the removal of construction and

column2: 2. Section 5-02 of subchapter E of Chapter 1 of Title 17 of the Rules of the City of New York is amended by adding new subdivisions (f) and (g) to read as follows:

column1: <u>(f) No later than October 31 of every odd-numbered year, the Commission will hold a public hearing on the maximum rates charged by a licensee for the collection, removal, disposal, or recycling of trade waste.&nbsp
column2: At least 30 days prior to the public hearing, the Commission will publish the date, time and location of the public hearing in the City Record and on the Commission website.&nbsp
column3: At the hearing, proponents of a change in the maximum rates may submit oral or written testimony.&nbsp
column4: The proponent of the rate change shall bear the burden of demonstrating, on an industry-wide basis, that existing rates are inconsistent with the standards for maximum rates set forth in &sect

column1: (g) In determining whether the maximum rates charged by licensees for the collection, removal, disposal, or recycling of trade waste will be adjusted, the Commission shall not be limited to evidence provided by proponents of a rate change pursuant subdivision (f) of this section and may consider any relevant factor affecting the trade waste industry or its customers, including but not limited to:
<u>(1) The Producer Price Index (PPI), as published by the United States Department of Labor Bureau of Labor Statistics
(2) Available data on the trade waste industry, including but not limited to:
<u>(b) Regulated service operating revenues (revenue generated from waste removal services associated with rate-regulated portion of business)

(3) Any other factor that may be relevant to assessing a fair and reasonable return to licensees and the protection of those using the services of such licensees from excessive or unreasonable charges.
